Ecco il testo da tradurre:

"La comprensione del concetto di "fare il bene" in filosofia morale è cruciale per analizzare diverse teorie etiche. Tradizionalmente, questa espressione si riferisce all'azione che promuove il benessere altrui, minimizza la sofferenza e contribuisce al progresso sociale. Tuttavia, l'interpretazione di "bene" può variare notevolmente a seconda del quadro teorico adottato.

Nell'utilitarismo, ad esempio, "fare il bene" significa massimizzare la felicità generale, anche a costo di sacrificare gli interessi di alcuni individui. In deontologia, invece, l'azione moralmente corretta è quella che rispetta determinati doveri e principi, indipendentemente dalle conseguenze.

È importante notare che la nozione di "bene" è spesso legata a valori culturali e sociali specifici, e ciò che è considerato "buono" in una cultura potrebbe non esserlo in un'altra. Pertanto, l'analisi filosofica di "fare il bene" richiede una riflessione critica sulle proprie presupposizioni e una comprensione delle diverse prospettive etiche."

The crisis in the automotive sector has evolved into a crisis affecting the entire industry, the supporting industries, related sectors, commercial networks, and consequently, services, presenting dramatic prospects in terms of employment.

I believe that even the dramatic decline in these latest enrollments for this month, reportedly less than thirty-three, less than twenty, etc., for some member states, demonstrates that it is not a crisis of a technologically obsolete sector; it does not originate within the sector, nor within this or that company, due to managerial errors.
It is a systemic crisis and, as such, must be addressed urgently and decisively by European institutions.
Some remedies appear to be identified, but it is important how to implement them, with what resources, and with what perspectives for innovation.
It is certainly necessary to support the demand; consumption is the sole driver of recovery.

But, while this response supports consumption—a medium-term response—I believe we must state that immediate credit support is necessary to resume production, pay for materials, and maintain employment, even in the face of a decline in orders and demand.
Therefore, the credit scope—but we were saying—is important, the *how*.
I, too, call for a stronger role for Europe here. It is important that European institutions provide a signal.

Once again, we find ourselves in this Chamber to defend a food, cultural, and rural heritage stemming from a tradition centuries old, an invaluable heritage that the world envies, representing a tremendous wealth for our economy and also for the identity of our Union.
A heritage that today risks facing serious difficulties due to the Commission’s and Council’s intention to abolish the Coupage ban for the production of rosé wines, an intention born under strong

pressure and will find its ratification without the possibility of intervention by Parliament, the body that officially represents the millions of citizens, both producers and consumers, who will be affected by this initiative.

The Commission proposes allowing red wines to be produced simply by blending red and white wines, as is done in countries that do not possess our expertise and professionalism, on the flimsy pretext of responding to international competition.
As the respondent to the query, I emphasize that lowering the quality of our productions—the result of centuries of traditions and research, of significant investments, of passion—

And a focus on detail is not the response we need, especially in a time of economic crisis like this, when the average consumer is certainly paying more attention to price than to a label inscription.

To counterbalance this decision, it would suffice to find a name for the new product and inform consumers of the existence of two different types of rosé, the differing quality of the products, and the importance of recognizing the work and efforts of industry professionals.
Who will pay for all of this?

Mr. President, I would first like to acknowledge the presence of the DTP party president, Mr. Ahmed Turk, who is here with us in the distinguished gallery and is following the debate.

Dear Ahmed, please know that we stand in solidarity with you, and that we support the democratic struggle your party is conducting in Turkey for the recognition of the fundamental rights of the Kurdish people.
We recognize in DTP an indispensable tool for the promotion of democracy in Turkey and, for this reason, we condemn with firmness the police operations that.
Prime Minister Erdoğan ordered against you, incarcerating all three vice presidents of the DTP, along with over three hundred militants and supporters.
The victory of the DTP in the latest local elections demonstrates that the DTP party is a party with strong democratic popular support.

The European Parliament, in its resolutions, has called on Prime Minister Erdoğan to initiate direct discussions with the DTP; instead, his response has been further repression, more police, greater authoritarianism, and more imprisonment.

Everyone knows that my parliamentary group and the left in Europe have thus far supported Turkey’s accession process to the European Union, while simultaneously advocating for the reform process in that country.

However, I believe that in these last two years and especially in recent months, Erdoğan has shown another face—that of a leader compromised with the worst elements of the Turkish military, who simply want to massacre Kurds.
The reform process is practically dead, prisons are filling with Kurds, and it is Erdoğan himself who is closing any prospect of Turkey's accession.
It is his, and solely his, responsibility for what is happening in the EU-Turkey relations and for the growing perplexity of European public opinion towards Turkey.

I want to send a very strong political message to Erdogan: either he makes the search for a political and negotiated solution to the Kurdish question a priority—and let me be clear, this passes through direct negotiations with the DTP—or we will be the ones to call for the suspension of the accession negotiations with the European Union.

The path to Turkey's accession to the Union passes through Diyarbakir and the DTP; otherwise, we—those who have supported the accession process here—will be calling for a period of reflection that risks becoming definitive.

The optimism of will and the work that even you, Honorable Romagnoli, have done and the contribution you have made to the report means that all together we can build the European Union, and the European Union is a reality also for us Italians.

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, it appears that the thousands of deaths that have occurred thus far due to asbestos, the tens of thousands of deaths that have occurred thus far due to asbestos,
of people who risk dying in the coming years due to prior exposure to asbestos; the latency period, we know, can reach fifteen and even twenty years—these factors count for absolutely nothing.
It appears the Eternit process initiated in Turin has not continued, concerning what happened in Casale Monferrato, where there is no family that has not experienced bereavement within its ranks.
The Member States should have, operationally, banned asbestos by applying the 1999 Directive.

The States should have protected exposed workers with all possible precautions, applying the 2003 directive, closing facilities, remediating contaminated sites, and compensating victims and populations.
This did not happen everywhere.
Little or nothing has been done.
I have already discussed the Turin trial, in which Swiss and Belgian employers are defendants.
All were aware that little had been done, and it is primarily industry that has evaded its responsibilities, acting within the web of inertia of public authorities.
Examples of inertia are evident, for instance, in Italy, at Brioni where asbestos has not been removed, at Porto Margherita, and at Cengio, where deaths continue to be recorded.
Today, industry is requesting that the Commission tolerate yet another exemption already granted for a limited time by the REACH regulation in 2006 concerning chrysotile asbestos fiber.

It is true, their application is limited to low-voltage electrolysis plants and only in a few facilities, but where industrialists claim the impossibility of any alternative substitute, with the consequence of plant closure.

A blackmail situation, but alternatives to this process have been found in Sweden, utilizing technologies in the replacement of asbestos-free membranes for low voltage, and an analogous solution has also been adopted for hydrogen production.
Why in some states yes and in others no?
For, as in the long battle to ban PCBs, countless omissions and reticences have occurred, even those endorsed by the DG Enterprise of the European Commission.
Even in this instance, a positive example was not set.

The 1999 directive on the ban of asbestos stipulated that the revision of such authorization had to be preceded by an opinion from the scientific committee on toxicology, which had never been produced.
That is how the Commission respects the directives.
not to mention the union, which claims it wasn't even consulted.
The European Parliament undertakes its efforts to comply with others.

This resolution requests that the Commission fill a legislative gap by 2009 regarding the prohibition of second-hand products containing asbestos, roof tiles, aircraft parts, and anything else that should be disposed of definitively.
Precise dates are set, once again, for a strategy to ban all types of asbestos by 2015, but these were targets already written in 1999.
Ten years have passed, and people have continued to die.
The GUE had claimed, among the first initiatives of this legislative term, the establishment of a Community fund to compensate victims, and ad hoc funds for decontamination.
The request was specific to the Commission, which today instead falls back on the will of multinational corporations.
It is instead necessary to move to concrete facts and commitments.
Only when these are based on the same requests as this resolution will we be able to be understanding.
Today this resolve is not evident; therefore, we vote against granting the exemption.

Thank you, Mr. President, and I wished to convey to President Buzek the pride that fills me at this moment in belonging to an important institution such as the European Parliament presided over by you.
I believe that the sacrifices made over the last twenty years in their country and that today allow those twelve countries mentioned earlier in this assembly to be represented strengthen Europe.
However, I also wish to convey to her my concern having listened to her program within her address, which should—and I hope it will—give strength to this Parliament.
I hope that what he announced to us will come to fruition.

I hope that the next President of the European Commission, certainly President Barroso, will want to hear from her for the strong words she has spoken, so that this Parliament can provide answers to more than…

550 million citizens who voted for us in this Europe, who wanted us and still want us, and who demand from this Parliament, from all of us, the answers that Europe has certainly attempted to give, but has not fully succeeded in providing.
Regarding this endeavor of yours, I invest my hopes in it, and I am certain that with it we will achieve the certainties you have outlined for us.

Mr. President, Commissioner, honorable colleagues, it is neither my intention, nor that of my group, which has supported and desired this debate, to transpose matters of Italian domestic politics to the European level.

The issue of freedom of information concerns us all, concerns the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at the community level, in order to counteract political and economic influences and to guarantee genuine pluralism in information.

The Italian anomaly, where the Prime Minister is also the owner of some of the most important private networks, consists precisely in the existence of a dangerous entanglement between media, political, and economic powers.

It is precisely for this reason that we are calling for European regulatory intervention, an intervention that, far from being an act of anti-Italian sentiment, should serve to safeguard the pluralism of information, preventing concentrations and conflicts of interest.

For this reason, today we ask the Commission to intervene as soon as possible, as this Parliament has also requested in the past, to equip the European Union with common rules to protect the freedom of information for all European citizens.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I am aware that on September 30th last, the Commission presented a study on indices of media pluralism in the Member States.
But in 2008, a report was voted on, with Marianne Micco as rapporteur, which invited the European Commission and the Member States to protect, and I quote verbatim, the multiplicity of…
to express opinions on the media, to defend the pluralism of information, to guarantee all citizens of the European Union equal access to free and diverse information channels.

Even earlier, in 2004, a report was voted on in Parliament, drafted by Bogert Quack, concerning the risks of infringement within the European Union of freedom of expression and information. It requested that the Commission present a communication on ensuring media pluralism in all Member States.
To date, the Commission has yet to provide clear answers to the requests of Parliament.

Please note, Madam Commissioner, that I have not mentioned my country nor my Prime Minister, but in this forum, as a European citizen, I ask you what the Commission intends to do at the European level to ensure that media pluralism is guaranteed in all Member States.
Thank you. Given that the discussion regarding the vote that took place yesterday in the Environment Committee has been raised so many times,
I would like it to be clear, instead, that it cannot all be reduced to a single extremist ideological position.

We have heard many diverse positions from our colleagues, positions that are far more elaborate, far more sensible, and therefore, being more closely aligned with reality, I believe are better able to provide real answers.
Science as a totem does not exist, and when this error of identifying a problem in such an ideological way has been made, answers have not been provided but rather
disasters, and Europe should be the teacher here, not repeating the same mistakes, even if in different guises and with labels that seem ostensibly much friendlier.
I must recall that the emissions trading directive itself stipulates that the virtuous path of the European Union is to be assessed by the Commission based on the outcomes of the conference.
We at the conference must go, certainly possessing strong positions, having clear ideas, but absolutely seeking to equitably divide the efforts.
Efforts among all industrialized countries, primarily, that must adopt equivalent emission reduction targets, but also without forgetting what the colleague Grostet so well recalled,

Among developing countries, we cannot avoid making distinctions. There are truly developing countries, and there are countries that have already emerged with their economies—I am speaking of India, China, and Brazil.
These are countries that cannot fail to assume their own commitments.
Instead, I strongly request that if an agreement is not reached in Copenhagen, the European Union continues to ensure the allocation of free allowances to at-risk sectors under Directive 2387/CE.

These are fundamental points; we want the Kyoto Protocol itself to maintain its environmental significance and, above all, to prevent the creation of a financial bubble at the expense of our European businesses.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, this is very important for two reasons: the first is the theme of research concerning the fight against neurodegenerative diseases, and the second is the modality of joint programming in research.
We would, of course, have preferred—and this has been stated and was the subject of our questioning—a more direct involvement of Parliament in the pilot project.

If we are not to halt matters now and must proceed, we request assurances that our opinion will be taken into consideration in the reception of the Competitiveness Council and that a more certain legal basis be clarified for the future for the full involvement of Parliament and for fuller ownership in this area of research.

Now we must intervene with adequate means and resources to prevent and eradicate a scourge as widespread as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and the other diseases destined to increase in the face of an aging population.
We request that focus be placed on large-scale, comprehensive studies, both diagnostic and therapeutic.

Crucial appear to be the investigations into biomarkers, early diagnosis methods based on a multidisciplinary approach, the establishment of extensive databases, the search for curative medications, and models of care and appropriate services.

I feel compelled to make only one request in this context: that neither the subjectivity of patients—too often excluded in this type of illness—nor the involvement of patient and family associations be overlooked.
Methodologically, we consider collaborative research projects to be very important because they address a fundamental need: that of concentrating efforts and resources.
to overcome those fragmentations, those duplications, and thus create a critical mass sufficient to yield adequate results for this type of research.

If one considers that in other areas of the world, joint public and private efforts result in investments of tens of millions of euros, we realize how much remains to be done and how much we must do, converging on projects.

shared, on strategic lines and programs shared between States and Europe, and on common programs between public and private entities, without neglecting that international framework which connects us with major scientific realities at the international level.
What are the novelties of the Stockholm Programme compared to those of the AIA? A fair balance between rights and security and legal protection in both criminal and civil fields.
Safety is a right: not to be assaulted in the workplace, to walk along the street without risking one’s life, not to be subjected to violence as women, not to be exposed to acts of terrorism.
States and Europe must guarantee security.
But a security measure that diminishes guarantees of liberty is an action that denies certainty to the law and is therefore a source of insecurity and barbarity.
Guantanamo.
Europe is the homeland of rights.
The Stockholm Programme defines them with meticulous detail.

Today, a fair balance between the discipline of anticriminal law enforcement and the everyday life of citizens—their familial, social, economic, work, and study relationships—all governed by civil law and civil justice.
This is Europe of the citizen.
and it will be constructed within the Member States and the Community institutions.
European society is more united, mobility more intense, than is commonly believed.
Taming is now a right.
The borders between States are not impermeable walls; they are networks through which society filters every day.
Stockholm provides the institutional framework for mutual judicial cooperation and a European justice, that of the national [courts].
and that communal, a European right, national and communal, a European citizen, a European judge, the national and the communal.

European rules are dictated by community regulations and the jurisprudence of European courts, but also originate from the behaviors of workers, businesses, students, national judges, and European networks among justice professionals.
Bottom-up, therefore, and this is a process originating from the ground. The Stockholm Programme seeks to support it.
Parliament has made a significant effort with this resolution, which I hope will be supported here by a broad, unified vote—a vote to which we have worked intensely.
The Council should respectfully take this into consideration.
Lisbon is not yet in implementation, but it is there, distinctly present.
Let the Council be ambitious, Minister, value what we have developed here and the wealth of suggestions that emerge from it.

Within the Budgetary Control Committee, I must acknowledge the very important work carried out by the Committee, the excellent work of the rapporteur, and I must also say that there was considerable political cohesion.

This is because from the outset we have wanted to convey a very clear message: we intend to work with great rigor to guarantee transparency, fairness, and legality in the management of public funds and, consequently, in the verification of budgets.
Significant progress has been made with the Council, which initially was unwilling to respond.
I personally attest to this to the Swedish Presidency, which has always sought to demonstrate its commitment to transparency and fairness.
Therefore, we anticipate further progress from this perspective, because it is, of course, absolutely unacceptable, particularly with the entry into force of the treaty of…
Lisbon, that the Parliament lacks information and news in order to verify the budget and public funds, in the interest not only of the European Union but also of all the citizens of Europe.
Honorable President, we were in Ramallah when the news arrived that Europe had adopted a new decision on the peace process in the Middle East.
We observed the hopeful smile of the Palestinian representatives.
They were intense days of emotions and suffering, etched on the faces of children clinging to the bars of their home windows, on Hebron’s street, the ghost street that no Palestinian can cross.

The suffering of an eighty-five-year-old woman evicted from her home, forced to sleep in the cold in a tent located in the garden of what had been her house, the suffering in the faces of those Palestinians who had built a farm with European funding, subsequently destroyed by Israeli soldiers.
Israel has the right to be an independent state, but Palestinians also have the right to have a homeland, a state, and a passport.
The Council of Europe’s decision marks a significant step forward, but action is needed immediately.
The conflict between Israel and Palestine is the tip of the iceberg of a larger conflict.
On the final day of the visit, Israeli authorities prevented us, the European Parliament delegation, from visiting the Gaza Strip.
I believe that on this matter, the High Representative, Baroness Ashton, must intervene to ensure that the protest of democratic Europe is heard.

I thank President De Rossa, who led the delegation, and all the other members of the delegation, because during the days we spent in Palestine, the vulnerable people of Palestine were able to see and hear the face and words of a Europe that defends rights and wants and must do more.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the European Union is committed to the fight against terrorism in all its dimensions.

When discussing the fight against terrorist offenses, it is necessary to ensure that fundamental rights are fully respected and that the measures adopted to combat terrorism are proportionate and effective.

The rights of the defense and fundamental procedural guarantees must therefore be fully respected by the institutions of the Union, even when defining lists of persons and identities, in this case linked to certain individuals.

Al Qaeda is subject to restrictive measures, and it is equally essential that these measures be subject to appropriate democratic and parliamentary oversight, as rightly prescribed by the Treaty of Lisbon.

It is therefore evident that, as also stated by the European Parliament's legal service, any measure of this type must follow the codecision procedure, allowing the representatives of European citizens to fully exercise their legislative and oversight roles.
Mr. President, I would like to avoid continuing to list the reasons for our disagreement with the Iranian government.
I would only like to emphasize, having not been cited here, that one of the most serious violations of civil rights is that directed towards young people.
Having the Iranian government, it has also signed the United Nations treaty for the protection of the child, while continuing instead to invest heavily in the detriment of minors.
I would like that, following this debate, on the one hand, Baroness Ashton commits to indicating a common line of action for all of Europe and the entire European Parliament.
one concerning the events in Iran and the other that the interparliamentary committee with the Iranian government take note that a change of course is needed.

I participated with my friends Scuria and Tattarella in the protest that we had formulated against the Commission, which, in any case, also with an official statement, declared its intention to travel to Iran, having instead firmly requested the possibility of meeting with the opposition and engaging in dialogue with it.

I would like the Commission, from this moment forward, to turn the page and establish relationships of assistance, support, and dialogue with the representatives of the opposition who are in exile, not least Ms. Miriam Raiavi, who represents this reality.
This is what the European community should do, rather than impose sanctions.

Colleagues, I intervene to highlight the gravity of the deindustrialization situations affecting several Sicilian industrial hubs, particularly the automotive sector in Termini Merese, Fiat Group, and the petrochemical sector in Gela, Eni Group.
The stagnation and damage caused by competition stemming from a low-wage system within certain Eurozone countries freeze out Asian competition.
In contrast to the processes of severe deindustrialization that are manifesting within widespread areas of the Union, I believe that the time has come to reconsider the line of non-return.
the intervention adopted to date by the European Commission and to begin implementing a package of measures to support relevant and strategic European industries.
This exhortation is primarily addressed to the European Commission and Commissioner Tajani for Industry.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the theme of fiscal good governance, although always of great importance, has acquired even greater topicality and relevance following the major economic and financial crisis of two years ago.
International, G20, and European leaders have discussed it and continue to do so, particularly when addressing tax evasion and tax havens.
All of this is important, it is a sign of commitment and will, but one must not entertain the illusion that an announcement alone is sufficient.
A serious and consistent policy is required.
There remain many problems still.
It is truly still far too easy to purchase or establish a shell company for tax evasion.
A simple search online reveals thousands of websites offering companies for acquisition, even in European Union countries.
Often, an email with a scanned copy of the passport attached is sufficient to open a company.
It is necessary to end the practice of creating fictitious legal entities to evade taxation.
This report that I present is based on the communication from the European Commission on fiscal good governance of April 28, 2009.
The report aims to advance concrete proposals and requests a strong commitment from the European Commission and the Council to implement these proposals.
It is necessary to consider the fight against tax havens, tax evasion, and the illicit flight of capital as a priority of the European Union.
From this derives the principle of good governance, which is founded on transparency, exchange of information, cross-border cooperation, and fair tax competition.
The point is that increasingly greater tax cooperation and collaboration are needed within the European Union.
The overarching objective we must set for ourselves is to achieve an automatic exchange of information on a global and multilateral scale, naturally beginning with the European Union.
As colleague Alvarez has already stated, the banking secrecy must be abolished entirely in European Union countries, bringing an end, without further delay, to the exemption regime.
temporary measure that authorizes the application of a withholding tax at source, often evaded or underestimated, in lieu of information exchange.
I do not wish to elaborate on the specific proposals contained within the report.
I emphasize that we nonetheless need to expand the scope of the 2003 Savings Directive, combat VAT fraud, and establish a public Union register.
that takes into account individuals or companies who have created companies or opened accounts in tax havens.

from the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base. Furthermore, the European Union must speak with a single voice on the international stage, advocating for the improvement of OECD regulations to achieve automatic exchange of information instead of exchange on request.

Mr. Commissioner Kovacs, please also consider the other reports. We need a strong commitment from the Commission, and we need, at this moment, to ensure that these priorities are emphasized to the new Commission at the time of the handover.
We will hold the Council and the European Commission accountable for the work.

On behalf of the European Parliament, I would like to thank my colleagues and, above all, the shadow rapporteurs for the contribution they have made to this work, which I hope will be approved by the Parliament.

I must admit that when we discuss the fight against terrorism, focusing solely on intelligence and technology, I always have the impression that we insist on examining the issue inadequately, as if we were treating an illness by concentrating only on its symptoms and not on its causes.
Is it not perhaps time to confront the problem of terrorism, aiming at the heart of the matter, rather than limiting oneself to its outward phenomenology?

Addressing the heart of the problem means, for example, becoming aware that terrorism is also a direct manifestation of the inability or unwillingness of ethnic groups to integrate into the European cultural fabric.
I ask and I request of this Parliament: do we want to discuss terrorism?
Then let this Parliament have the courage to politically address a debate on the degree of integration of Muslims in Europe and on their propensity to share Western values, rights, and freedoms.
In this regard, I submitted a question to the Commission regarding full-face veils to encourage this Assembly to openly address the issue.
It appears there is no willingness whatsoever to address the topic.
I ask and I request of you, honorable colleagues from all political groups, if not on these topics, on which others should the political voice of the peoples of Europe be heard?

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the conclusion of negotiations with Croatia by two thousand and twelve is a feasible objective, and the Svoboda report highlights, in a balanced manner, the progress made and the steps still to be taken.
Now, it is justice that is the sector in which further decisive reforms are needed.
And it is, indeed, not enough to complete the necessary systemic reforms and to approve new laws and to cooperate as needed with the Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
I insist on the necessity of creating a genuine legal culture and mindset in line with European standards.

The independence of the judiciary, a central issue, becomes crucial, as does the training, recruitment, and career progression of judges, meaning the absence of any kind of influence exerted by the government on judicial decisions.
I appeal to the Commission to consider the need for decisive measures in this regard during the final phase of the negotiation.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, the accession of Croatia to the European Union reinforces the consolidation of a European identity, capable of expressing the common values of the new Europe, without obscuring, but rather integrating the specificities of its many facets.

The Republic of Croatia has made appreciable efforts to align with the required parameters, particularly in combating organized crime through new anti-mafia measures, but needs to undertake further efforts, especially in the judicial sector, before the negotiations of 2010 can be concluded.

Further steps can be taken by the institutions of the Republic of Croatia to align with what is foreseen in the first protocol of the European Convention on Human Rights signed in Paris in nineteen fifty-two, considering the restitution of nationalized property to its legitimate owners.
Mr. President, once again recently in Italy there has been an environmental disaster: the Lambro River and the Po River.
Recently, the Court of Justice of Luxembourg has condemned Italy for the danger to public health, for the unlawful disposal of waste, and for failing to control waste collection in the countryside.
And news from recent days concerning the increase in leukemia cases in Taranto linked to ILVA, as well as the asbestos disposal in schools in Crotone, and dioxin in Campania.
It is a continuous environmental disaster.

I formally request that the Commission state what measures it intends to take to ensure that the Italian government complies with the standards of European Union directives, with particular regard to the Court of Justice’s ruling of the other day.
justice, which has severely condemned Italy, which failed to manage waste disposal in Campania, has exposed the city of Naples to public ridicule for many weeks and months worldwide.

This debate is not a formality, but rather aims to be highly concrete, posing clear and precise questions regarding resources, their sources, and I hope, the Parliament hopes, that the answers provided today and in the upcoming councils on March 12th and 25th will be equally clear and precise.

We wish to firmly state to the Commission and the Council that the European Union, which has raised before the world the banner of the fight against atmospheric emissions and the climate challenge, today has a duty of coherence if it does not want to lose credibility.
must do everything possible to ensure these objectives are achieved.

We must be very clear that talking about a low-emission economy means a kind of Copernican revolution for the production system; it means changing many things, having clear priorities, political will, but above all, adequate resources and tools.
We also know that this Copernican revolution is essential for our production system, European industry, to remain competitive.
I mean that in many countries, in many research centers, in many universities, the intelligence is ready, the capabilities exist, the will is present; it is now a matter of igniting this engine.
They must do it, the Commissioner said, the Council said, the Member States must do it, businesses, private entities.
But I believe the task is fundamentally to bring together this complex partnership, both within the European Union.
To constructively address the employment problem, the key directives within the community framework are three: react, evolve, and protect.

To react, that is, to abandon the celebratory tones of Europropaganda, to address in a concrete manner the problems that afflict EU citizens, ensuring a direct connection between the world of education and the needs of the market and the territory, and requalifying among young people the perception of manual professions.

to evolve, that is, to make the EU 2020 strategy a positive synthesis between the requests of businesses and those of workers, in favor of a labor market in which flexicurity in contractual arrangements responds to the instability of market demand.

to protect, that is, to provide employment for those who have lost it, prioritizing our own citizens. Member States should therefore assess immigration policies based on actual immigration needs, and with twenty-three million unemployed, the possibility of halting extra-EU immigration for a few years should be considered.
I see no other ways to protect our work and our social system.
Concrete actions, courage, and decentralization are needed.

Mr. President, this concerns an oral amendment to point 13, wherein the Commission is invited to verify, given the current situation, the possibility of providing humanitarian aid in light of the situation.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, I would like to reiterate once again the importance of the written declaration on corruption that I proposed together with four other Members of Parliament, and which the majority of the European Parliament has approved, in order to obligate the Council and the Commission to a truly effective legislative framework regarding corruption.

I have returned on behalf of the Budgetary Control Committee from a visit to Greece, and it is certainly the case that one of the reasons for the Greek structural crisis also depends on the squandering of public funds, a situation that also occurs in Italy.

Eroded by corruption, as evidenced in recent days, corruption that primarily circulates through the illegal management of public funds, the relationship between a segment of the political class and a segment of business leaders, and white-collar organized crime.

It is important that the European Parliament exert all of its pressure on the Commission, on the Member States, that Member States failing to comply be sanctioned, and that the European institutions responsible for combating corruption and organized crime be strengthened.
We are well aware that this difference is even more pronounced within the scope of autonomous activities.
Indeed, women are too often compelled to sacrifice their professional ambitions in the name of assuming a role and the workload that derives from absolute dedication to family.

To resolve this issue, I believe it is necessary to implement measures such as those contained in the directive we are discussing, but always keeping a fixed gaze on the North Star of the family. Only this can give meaning and hope of success to these very measures.

Freeing women from the agonizing dilemma of choosing between the roles of mother, wife, and entrepreneur means lightening the burden of familial work and directly addressing concrete issues through positive and specific measures to support families.
Placing the family at the center is essential; otherwise, any package of measures will be a disjointed collection of interventions, ultimately futile.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Commissioner, we are meeting today to discuss organ transplantation, which undoubtedly represents one of the most positive aspects of progress in the healthcare field.
but on the other hand, it opens up a whole series of problems concerning the rights of the donor and the patient that must be addressed on an ethical, social, legal, and economic level.
This involves activating a virtuous pathway that addresses the serious imbalance between needs and the quantity of organs available, without compromising the principle of free and voluntary donation.

every form of illegal commercialization and trafficking, ensuring the quality and safety of organs intended for transplantation, with measures that effectively balance confidentiality and traceability.

It follows naturally that, in a context of cross-border exchanges and significant differences between the transplant systems adopted in the various Member States, such objectives can only be achieved by promoting coordination and cooperation.
In this regard, I believe it would be very important to establish a European database and adopt common quality and safety standards.
We must, however, be careful not to introduce unnecessary forms of rigidity or create further bureaucratic burdens that compromise what is currently done correctly and effectively.
Here, it would be not only contrary to our objectives, but also opposed to our aims.
Mr. President, I thank the rapporteur for the excellent work carried out on the European Union’s accession to the Convention on Human Rights, which has been approved by the European Commission.

represents a benefit for European citizens, because thanks to it there will be a new external Tribunal to the European Union to ensure that the rights of European citizens are always respected by the European Union and its Member States.

In virtue of the principle of democracy, the European Union and its Member States must always have the right to defend themselves. For this reason, I believe it is fundamental that every nation adhering to the Convention must have a judge to explain the context of each appeal.

It is important that the European Parliament has an informal body with the purpose of coordinating the exchange of information between the Parliament and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council, and it is important that the Parliament is also consulted and involved in the negotiation process.
I would also add that European citizens have the right to understand the mechanisms of this accession, just as they have the right to know what their rights are.

Therefore, I believe it is fundamental that the Council of Europe and the European Union consider the development of guidelines, with a clear explanation of all the effects and implications that accession will entail.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, one hundred and seventy measures in five years—numbers too ambitious for a program lacking a genuine character, particularly on certain issues.
Regarding migration, the program—beyond official documents—reveals an embarrassing weakness. What is the point of promising to strengthen bodies and agencies if a political strategy is then lacking?

A truly useful strategy must be based on several key principles: combating irregular immigration along the southern border, sharing the burdens of countering irregular migration among all European states, a policy of agreements with third countries, and, above all, the recognition that immigration during times of crisis is not an asset.
From the Parliament’s homepage, we read that more than twenty percent of young people in Europe are unemployed.
In a continent with twenty-five million unemployed, the Commissioner for Internal Affairs states that the migration issue must be based on solidarity.

We must instead reason with concreteness and realism. Today, the priority is to provide employment for our citizens; everything else is complacent rhetoric that helps neither the integration of immigrants nor, least of all, our own people.
Madam President, please excuse me, I wish to take this opportunity to bring to the Presidency’s attention the need to intervene regarding the connections a.
that flights between Strasbourg and European capitals are direct and do not continue to create inconvenience for those who must take three or four flights to reach Strasbourg.
Please intervene appropriately.

The national financial challenges of these months and years, the new Lisbon Treaty with its new responsibilities, the challenge we have set ourselves with Europe 2020, demand the mobilization of new and substantial financial resources.
The paradox we are witnessing even in this discussion is that, as things stand, both the Commission and the Council appear silent, unable to choose and to determine decisions.
And yet we know that if we want to emerge from the difficult economic and social phase, if we want to address the major challenges of the environment, the development of cohesion policy, and the
in agriculture in the coming years, we have a need to invest more in Europe and in the function of Europe and therefore in the essential function of Europe, that is, in its budget.
Therefore, we must not be afraid to discuss, even in a phase of financial constraints, investing more in resources.
having the strength and capacity to develop a debate and a discussion that places the theme of greater resources alongside the theme of greater quality and greater flexibility in their use.
And this is the challenge that lies before us.
Mr. President, honourable colleagues, the European Parliament is called upon, as we know, to issue a final opinion on food information to consumers.
It should be immediately stated that this was objectively a laborious, lengthy, and controversial legislative process, which could not be shortened.

It concerns, in fact, harmonizing Community food law through regulations designed to render information transparent to consumers, avoiding misleading them into confused or potentially harmful choices, even regarding their health.

The report by the Honourable Sommer, to whom due recognition is owed for the effort made to synthesize multiple needs, therefore aims to remedy contentious and disparate information systems currently in place in the countries of the Union.

It is no coincidence that national regulations currently differ in the denominations used to describe the nature of foods sold, creating a system that varies from country to country and fostering unfair competition to the detriment of potential consumers.
Thus, based on the European Commission’s proposal, efforts have been made to modernize existing legislation, engaging both the food industry and consumers.
Simultaneously, the report commits the European food industry to providing clarity on mandatory indications and on the presentation of food and nutritional values.

In a globalized market, the European Union could not refrain from adapting, and innovating, the legislation on food products to better protect food trade, safeguarding it from increasingly invasive and unrestrained international competition.

It is not new that we hear more frequently about the perversity of food products than about the deceptive denominations and indications that often do not meet the food requirements, yet are nonetheless marketed as beneficial foods for human health.
Madam Commissioner, we requested this oral questioning and a parliamentary resolution to clarify with the Commission that
Within the framework of the Stockholm Programme, the construction of a widespread European legal culture on our territory is highly important.

I should like to state immediately that this is important, but also that, in view of the communication the Commission will have to produce on future pilot projects, as has been said, we would like to clarify a few concepts.
Before the consultations begin promptly—the consultations of Parliament, in the meantime—and reach their initial phase, when the idea begins to take shape.
of these future projects so that we do not arrive too late when the projects are already formulated quite comprehensively.
I say this because we have certain fundamental observations to make.
Considering that the national magistrate, the lawyer of the individual States, is today a decisive piece in the construction of Europe.
because, by interpreting even national rights within a European framework, it provides the conditions for resolving conflicts and regulating the daily lives of citizens.
Thus, it establishes European citizenship, thus establishes a European sensibility for all those who live on these territories so that they may feel it with their children.
advantages that the introduction of European elements into all areas of national law and, therefore, particularly of Community law, brings to the lives of citizens.
Genuine advantages are offered to address a range of problems that would otherwise remain unresolved.
I wish to convey with this that we would like to slightly reverse the setup.
For example, we would not agree that these projects be styled like Erasmus, because the number of magistrates and lawyers involved in Erasmus-style projects would be.
very low, as must be the case, given the high costs of physical mobility in this field and therefore not very relevant within the overall context of the judiciary.
But the most important matter concerns the term “familiarization of courses” that we introduced in our document.

Judges are not schoolchildren sitting at desks being lectured; they are mature individuals, possessing a high degree of professionalism, with limited time available for this, not easily moved, but they bring

knowledge in itself and must be stimulated so that this knowledge is tested against the new problems of European law and European culture, creating conditions for exchange that are predominantly virtual rather than purely virtual.

physical, utilizing technologies, the network, and the various opportunities that can determine these exchanges, starting not so much from a general framework, but from individual cases, from the individual problems that magistrates and lawyers encounter.
that are new and that must stimulate the professional growth of these legal operators, within a genuine incentive.
to contribute to the reflection on their lived experiences, on what they have learned, in order to respond to the challenges that Europe poses in positive terms.

As you can see, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, we intend to introduce something new to the tradition of courses that have been held until now and which we find scarcely effective for this purpose.

We need to know how many funds are available and what they are. To express a doubt regarding the idea, as written in the communication, of a central European institution governing this process, because we are in favor of a bottom-up movement, and not instead a centralization.
This is a new configuration.

What we intend to convey, however, is that if a European mindset is not formed among magistrates and lawyers, who in this way offer their services to justice and to the citizens who request it, we will not make Europe.
Therefore, this is not just an important document for European justice, but an important document for the entire development of European unity.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the proposal on the rights of bus passengers aims to improve and protect passengers, particularly those with disabilities or reduced mobility.
This concerns the first regulation on passenger rights in bus transport and should guarantee passengers, as already happens in the rail and air sectors.
The second reading position aims to establish a series of rights for passengers who decide to travel by bus.

I concur with the speaker Cancian’s line of reasoning, whom I thank for the excellent work performed, and I believe that the scope of application of the regulation should be modified, excluding regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be just and necessary to guarantee the rights of passengers in the event of accidents, cancellations, or delays at departure, as had already been decided in the first reading by Parliament.

Equally important is the matter of passenger rights information. It would indeed be useful to provide passengers with information regarding connections with other modes of transport. This will also ensure dialogue between passenger transport services via bus and those via rail.

Regarding individuals with disabilities and those with reduced mobility, it is necessary to guarantee the utmost protection, and I would propose a twenty-four-hour timeframe instead of forty-eight, to request assistance, as well as increased guarantees for compensation and replacement of the tools that ensure the mobility of people with disabilities in the event of loss or damage.
Furthermore, taking into account the needs of passengers with reduced mobility, any architectural barrier should be eliminated and existing infrastructure improved to ensure accessibility.
This regulation aims to enhance the competitiveness of the bus sector, promote intermodality, but above all, to improve passenger travel conditions.

Mr. President, I thank the rapporteur, Mr. Sterks, who has done an excellent job on this report, which addresses how to extend free movement in the maritime sector for navigation within the European Union.
I share with the rapporteur the objective of this directive, namely to exempt all maritime transport of goods within the European Union from unnecessary administrative formalities.

Indeed, to have a borderless European maritime space, it is not only important that the various competent authorities cooperate satisfactorily, but also that the various simplification systems are applied simultaneously.
This is necessary to ensure the proper functioning of the entire European maritime space without borders, to ensure that sea freight is more attractive and used in an optimal manner.

The harmonization of administrative procedures between Member States will allow for smoother navigation between the various ports of the European Union and will reinvigorate maritime freight traffic, which currently accounts for less than ten percent of the total.
To date, navigation continues to be hindered by the administrative formalities imposed upon it.
Electronic systems should therefore be activated as quickly as possible, as this would facilitate a faster data exchange system.

Furthermore, interoperability is essential for achieving genuine administrative simplification. Indeed, initiating information exchange via email is not entirely efficient and proves futile if the information systems are not technically interoperable.
As for language, I believe that the use of a common language would certainly benefit European maritime navigation.
In this way, communication would be more efficient, causing less confusion and fewer administrative delays.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would first of all like to offer special congratulations to our rapporteur, the Honorable Kramer, because we all know that we have achieved a result that at times seemed unexpected.
I would like to recall that this directive, this dossier was genuinely considered a dossier at risk of conciliation proceedings.
Therefore, we have also heard from the Commissioner’s words, and it is evident to all that we are facing a complex undertaking that has required considerable time.
Consider merely a directive from nineteen fifty-six, and this work brings us to the fifth and most significant amendment of the industrial emissions directive.
These few data alone, I believe, reveal to us all the shortcomings and even the defects of this legislation.

I would like to recall that a directive of difficult implementation concerns nine Member States subject to infringement procedures and possesses such a broad scope as to sometimes prove even inappropriate.

All of this has entailed considerable effort, has required sacrifices from all the institutions involved, from all the political groups, from all the national delegations, and has frequently presented us with truly difficult choices.

However, I am here this evening to say with conviction that, in my opinion, we have achieved the best possible results in safeguarding competition, the environment, European industrial and employment policy.
We truly have, on the one hand, a directive that imposes common obligations on all Member States, but on the other, a directive that also allows for the flexibility that is necessary.

Indeed, I genuinely hope that the results of this restructuring will, in the immediate term, also entail a reduction in administrative burdens and, in the medium term, an improvement in environmental performance and a strengthening of European industry.
Mr. President, I would like to underscore the situation in which the crisis presents a reality to which, for too long, due consideration has not been given.
namely, the instability in Central Asia, which is unfortunately growing, while hopes for democracy and economic progress, at least in some of these countries, prove to be particularly fragile.

Kyrgyzstan has suffered in the last month from extremely harsh repercussions that will leave, at least in the immediate future, a legacy of interethnic hatred that will make the country's stabilization even more difficult than it was previously.
The task of the international community and the European Union in particular, as has already been stated, is to assist Kyrgyzstan as much as possible under three aspects.
Secondly, through long-term economic assistance as regards the European Union within its

strategy for Central Asia and the instruments implemented in that context, through political support to underpin the process of returning to constitutional legality and the establishment of a genuine rule of law.
The constitutional referendum, held in crisis from 28 June, in obviously very difficult conditions, can be considered a first step on the road back to a constitutional order.

The electoral process of June 28th, among other things, received a positive assessment from the OSCE observation mission, which, of course, took into account the special conditions under which the referendum was held.
The new constitutional order of Kyrgyzstan will be more oriented toward a parliamentary system than toward a presidential one.
This may allow for a better consideration of the country’s diverse ethnic composition and the need to garner consensus from the various components of a nation so fragmented and complex.
The European Union and the Crisis are linked by a partnership and cooperation agreement that provides for regular meetings of a parliamentary cooperation committee.
It is our hope that our interparliamentary relations can resume as soon as possible with the participation of a credible, democratically elected Parliament.
In the immediate term, the crisis, as already mentioned, requires stability and our political-economic assistance. Let us not be parsimonious in either.
Mr. President, esteemed members of the European Council—whom no one elected—today we also have a rotating presidency held by a government of no confidence from its own citizens.

This alone would suffice to understand why Europe is experiencing a profound crisis, an Europe that is now a political paradox in the hands of a political elite in which citizens do not recognize themselves.
The Belgian non-Presidency programme discusses structural reforms, employment growth, financial stability, and competitiveness, with the chosen instrument being the EU 2020 strategy.
The current crisis, however, should spur Europe to ingredients quite different from those that led to failure.

A comprehensive reassessment is necessary, because the crisis is not a reflection of decline, but rather a death certificate for the European social model that Europropaganda would instead administer as a cure.
Today, Europe is a vast edifice collapsing in on itself under the weight of democracy, centralism, and obstacles to free enterprise.
To emerge from the crisis, Europe must change its vocabulary: more decentralization, less bureaucracy, greater practicality, and attention to the real problems of citizens.
Everything else will only inexorably accelerate the decline.
Mr. President, thank you, I apologize. I would like to emphasize in this intervention how the progressive erosion of European farmers’ incomes at the expense of increasingly

Profit margins within the agroindustrial supply chain are generating a concerning economic marginalization of those employed in the agricultural sector, resulting in the abandonment of these activities.
Therefore, a change of course is required, a shift that the European Commission itself acknowledges, and which the report under consideration by the Chamber this morning confirms.
Following this morning’s chamber approval, to which I wish to express my support, it highlights with extensive justifications and suggestions, including legislative and behavioral aspects.
It is, indeed, necessary to combat global commodity speculation and guarantee supply security.

Furthermore, greater price transparency must be ensured, not only to deliver fairness and dignity to farmers, but also to correct the significant power imbalances that currently exist and to prevent abuses among the various operators.
Agriculture must reaffirm itself as a sector of economic and social stability and regain power within the mercantile context of the European Union.
Mobilism and myopia—this is the diagnosis of the malaise afflicting Europe 27 today.

The issue of employment, because if one in four young people in Italy is without work and sixteen million unemployed are counted in the Eurozone, is also due to the fact that, following the noise of Eurozone propaganda in recent months, no genuinely effective action has ensued.

Myopia because Europe, in indicating the way out of the crisis, not only represented the usual recipe, but completely lost sight of the most inherently territorial dimension of economic and social cohesion policy.

Only by placing the territory at the center of political action, only by respecting its unique cultural vocations, can European policies for development and employment restart, drawing sustenance from those natural energies that every geographic area expresses: districts, small and medium-sized enterprises, and artisanal crafts.
To address the employment problem, one must first think on a smaller scale, invest in local authorities, and prioritize subsidiarity, safeguarding a heritage of linguistic and cultural diversity.
If the compass of European policy does not guide it toward the territory, the failure of the Euro project is a certainty.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, in the construction of a Europe of rights, a central place is held by freedom of information, pluralism of information, and the independence of information.

The Commissioner, the Commissioneress, has observed that there is a country of the European Union – moreover, a founding member of the European Union under the Treaty of Rome – where it does not exist.
There is a plurality of information, where a Prime Minister directly or indirectly controls public and private television and the printed press.
What democratic electoral competition is possible in a country where a Prime Minister or a political party controls the media?
What democracy can exist in a country where a law is about to be passed that prevents journalists from publishing judicial news?
Forget Watergate, forget the press as guardian of the regime, a pampered lapdog. What democratic country is it where the internet is sought to be brought under control?
What democratic country is one where those who oppose the prevailing orthodoxy are marginalized, and free expression of thought and dissent are not guaranteed?

We are not describing the Sudan of Bokassa nor the Romania of Ceaușescu and the Italy of Berlusconi, where this, unfortunately, also occurs because the European Commission lacks the courage to assert an autonomous and independent position vis-à-vis the Member States.
The completion of the internal market for postal services by the end of this year is an important step, but would be

It would be appropriate for the Commission to conduct an impact assessment, as some colleagues who preceded me have recalled, of the opening of the postal market, in order to better understand the needs of citizens.

How does the Commission intend to protect the right of European citizens living in areas that are difficult to reach, such as mountainous or rural zones, to receive mail regularly, and what tools does the Commission intend to adopt to ensure this occurs?
I also believe that this directive, which already exists, should not be exploited to justify the problem of social dumping.
It is the Member States that must implement the directive and they all possess the instruments to do so.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, today’s debate on readmission agreements cannot avoid the increasingly thorny issue of the agreement between the European Union and Libya.
We know that a portion of the agreement is focused on combating illegal immigration.
We are concerned because, to date, the Commission has told us very little about this, despite the Treaty of Lisbon obliging the Commission itself to inform Parliament promptly.
Libya, as is well known, has not ratified the Geneva Convention on Human Rights, nor has it to date demonstrated adherence to international law.

I think of the case of Eritrean immigrants detained in an inhumane manner at the Libyan Brak detention center, or still to the closure of UNHCR offices, but I think especially of what happened last week, when a Libyan Coast Guard vessel opened fire.

against an Italian fishing vessel from the Marina of Mazzara del Vallo present in international waters, with the justification of the presence of undocumented migrants on board, a very serious justification that leads us to believe that the agreement signed between Libya and Italy which

It also provides for the rejection of immigrants to Libya without provisions relating to the right to request asylum and individual case-by-case examinations of their circumstances, and includes the possibility of using firearms to stop immigrants.

Given that, in this case as well, part of the agreement is confidential, I wonder whether the Commission is aware of its content, or whether it does not deem it necessary, in this specific instance, to request clarification.
The Commission has proposed the possibility for Libyan authorities to open fire on vessels if there is suspicion of transporting irregular migrants.

Economically, it is beneficial for Europe to deepen trade relations with rapidly growing neighboring countries. However, the EU has consistently, at least in principle, pursued a trade policy toward third countries, taking into consideration social and humanitarian aspects.
We must then assert these clauses with firm resolve towards Turkey, a country that is becoming increasingly Islamized, in which the condition of women is progressively deteriorating.
women killed in 2009 in domestic violence cases, a country where Christians live in fear of attacks by Islamist extremists, it is enough to recall the brutal murder of Monsignor Padovanese.

In the report, Parliament encourages Turkey to assume a leading role in promoting fair and open trade. One thing is certain: we must be concerned about the leadership role Turkey is seeking to carve out for itself in the Arab world.

friendship that Turkey is cultivating with Iran and terrorist groups such as Hamas. In any case, if trade policy must be, let it be, but this must never become the Trojan horse for facilitating Turkey’s entry into Europe.
Mr. President, honourable colleagues, Commissioner, this measure aims to strengthen and rationalize the European Union's pharmacovigilance system.
These are the ambitious objectives set forth in the McEwan documents, amending respectively Regulation 726/2004 and Directive 2001/83/EC.
Thanks to intensive and efficient coordination between the Council and the European Parliament, and the parliamentary committees competent for the subject matter.
to arrive at discussing today a proposal that aims to improve the Community pharmacovigilance system and to refine the substantial and multi-decennial activity of the European Union in this sector.

Simplification, transparency, and rationalization can be considered key points of these two reports, which propose measures aimed at ensuring the best possible protection of public health, based on standards harmonized throughout Europe.

Reference is made, indeed, to a wide range of interventions that span from a more precise definition of roles and responsibilities of the principal national and supranational stakeholders to a new and more consciously active involvement of the patient.

it recognizes a fundamental actor role within the system, in strengthening the transparency of information regarding the safety of medicines, and in simplifying activities related to communication, registration, and evaluation of alleged adverse effects.
The current pharmacovigilance system must be improved, also through closer collaboration at European, national, and regional levels.
Effective participation at all three of these levels will indeed ensure a productive exchange of information concerning the adverse reactions of medications.
The new pharmacovigilance system will be capable of ensuring a high level of shared and secure information to benefit patients, national authorities, and healthcare professionals.
Mr. President, it is precisely these days here in Brussels that the men who waged the war have gathered.

Many representatives from municipalities and regions have discussed how to address the serious problems affecting the lives of our cities, the old and new needs concerning workers, families, and small and large productive businesses.
The economic crisis that has befallen our societies has made it harder and more difficult for everyone to provide adequate responses to a new, serious social issue.
In this context, I believe everyone has understood that cohesion policy has, on many occasions, been the only concrete tool available to territories to attempt to provide responses.
Consequently, we can state that cohesion policy has been, in recent years, for all regions, an essential lever for the process of European integration.
Now we find ourselves redefining this policy for the post-2002 era; we are therefore at a turning point.
For this reason, it is vital to avoid certain risks.
The initial fundamental principle is that any of its renationalization would be a serious step backward.

Subsequently, it is necessary to ensure, in the construction of the funding plan, adequate provision, both for the needs of the most vulnerable entities and simultaneously for the capacity to avoid penalizing the most competitive and advanced regions.
Finally, it is essential to simplify procedures for those who have demonstrated efficiency and to strengthen the capacity to sanction those who have not.
We expect the Commission to move in that direction.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the road to a Europe tailored to women is still long and difficult.
The statistics speak clearly: the global crisis has struck the labor market, severely testing female employment, which in 2008 decreased further by seven-tenths of a percentage point.

Despite the provocations concerning equal opportunities and employment that periodically fill a declining Europropaganda, to date no concrete measures have been adopted to guarantee women genuine fulfillment as both worker and mother.
The Europe of the future needs to radically rethink its welfare model and not simply change its label periodically.

Therefore, the directive concerning the harmonization of maternity leave across Europe is positive, but inefficient is the choice to address, within the same report, the complementary and equally important matter of paternity leave, treating it on the periphery.

Greater integration of women is not merely a moral value, but also a strategic objective for the sustainability of the much-touted European social model, which continues not to convince me due to the lack of results.
The rapporteur of the Development Committee, the honourable Mitchell, has asked me to substitute for him because he is unable to be present today.
I thank you for the work completed with your usual punctuality and for the quality of your proposals, which have garnered the favorable, I would say unanimous, opinion of the Development Committee.
For what I will say, but especially for what my colleague Michel has done to date, I am convinced that the report can be voted on with a broad majority.
But I will now turn to the discussion.
During 2009, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation 1905/2006 establishing a financial instrument for development cooperation.
With this proposal, the Commission had requested that Parliament approve an amendment allowing non-governmental organizations to benefit from tax advantages when operating in developing countries.
Proposal accepted by us.
But the cooperation and development regulation also contains the implementing rules for the European Union's development policy.
These rules stipulate that when the Commission must allocate funding, it is required to follow comitology procedures.

This means that Parliament has the power to examine these funding proposals and, should the Commission exceed its remit, Parliament can adopt resolutions in order to request the Commission to modify the decisions in question.

Only from 2006 to the present has Parliament considered that, in at least twelve cases, the Commission had exceeded its implementing powers, but in only three of these cases has the Commission actually modified or withdrawn its decision proposal.
Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the Development Committee proposed applying the procedure for delegated acts provided for in Article 299 of the Treaty of Lisbon.
The adoption of these procedures would mean that, at least in strategic funding decisions which the European Commission must adopt, Parliament would have a more significant role.
Indeed, according to the Treaty of Lisbon, in certain, well-defined cases, the Parliament may delegate to the Commission the power to make strategic decisions.
In our view, the selection of countries to which the European Union should provide development assistance

It is a choice that rests with the legislature. And so, which sectors should be prioritized for funding: education, healthcare, environmental protection, the capacity for good governance, the development of small businesses?
And how to ensure transparency in the management of development aid?
These are the areas and subjects in which the European Parliament should play a more significant role than it has in the past.
It is here that the legislature must provide precise guidance to the executive.
And it is precisely this direction in which, I believe, the requests of European citizens ultimately go.
I genuinely hope for the widest possible consensus regarding this report by Mr. Mitchell.
To the speaker. On politics.

An integrated maritime Union needs to move beyond a phase of good intentions and provide new impetus to a strategy that will serve as a catalyst for growth and development of the European Union, addressing the enormous delays accumulated in the prevention of environmental disasters, the fight against climate change, and against pollution.
This very morning, our colleague Pirillo brought to the Parliament's attention yet another catastrophic event that occurred in recent days in the city of Paola, Calabria.

The Commission must demonstrate concrete action, operating not only with governance tools but implementing targeted legislative measures, drawing the necessary lessons from past errors, due to an approach often too sectoral.
There is full awareness that this process is very complex, but we are in the midst of a difficult and demanding crossing that cannot tolerate lapses in attention and requires adequate investments and

mechanisms of participatory governance, both at the interinstitutional level and in international cooperation for regional basins, among which the Mediterranean stands out due to the complexity of its jurisdiction.
It is for this fundamental reason that understanding the management of the Mediterranean basin as a shared heritage of all riparian states is crucial, based on the principle of the

Alternatively, the increasingly common practice of unilaterally declaring exclusive economic zones or similar areas in the Mediterranean Sea, in addition to being inconsistent with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, would undermine the concept of effective and shared governance.

I recall, in this connection, that only a month ago this interpretation by Libya resulted in a veritable armed assault against a European fishing vessel, and it would be mistaken to maintain that this is purely an Italo-Libyan affair.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, I thank Ms. Meissner for the report on integrated maritime policy. I concur with the rapporteur regarding the necessity of strengthening maritime transport and shipbuilding, and of protecting coastal regions, as well as fostering innovation and research activities.
Today, maritime transport plays a fundamental role in the commercial sphere.
Therefore, cooperation between small and large ports facing the same maritime basin should be encouraged, facilitating a more fluid exchange of trade.
Furthermore, to ensure intermodality, it is necessary to invest in port and hinterland infrastructure, particularly that of ports which can be connected to European corridors.
Finally, I believe it is important not to overlook another theme, namely that of port security.

It is necessary that there be a homogenization of all security measures within all European ports, in order to better safeguard maritime transport and to prevent unfair competition at the expense of those ports that, instead, in order to ensure greater security, must face higher expenses.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, thirty years ago Morocco denied for many years that there was a war with the Sahrawi people; today it is denying that there is a disproportionate repression against the same people.
Yet, in Western Sahara, there are deaths and injuries among a population that claims only the right to live in freedom in its own land.
Morocco has substantially closed its borders to anyone who might be a witness to these events.
No information and no representatives.
Access was denied by a French deputy and our colleague Meyer.
Europe watches passively.
There is no indication in the Commission’s communication that places us subordinate to the mediation of the UN, which continues to fail as it has for the last thirty years.
There is no statement from Ms. Ashton, who is responsible for foreign policy.
It is necessary to respond with a position statement from Parliament.
It is necessary to react towards Morocco by halting every initiative regarding trade agreements, beginning with the renewal of fishing agreements.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, my contribution is not intended to be the usual Eurosceptic rhetorical exercise, but an impetus for the EU to pay more attention to substance than to form, and to abandon propaganda in favor of practicality.
Having failed the Lisbon strategy, Europe crafted a new slogan, "EU 2020," but in reality, it provided no innovative response to employment challenges.

The data confirms it: 9.6% is the unemployment rate in Europe, 20.2% the youth rate. In Italy, the third net contributor to the EU budget, the situation for young people is even more dramatic, with 25.9% of young people without employment.

In the Europe I envision, there are no wasted resources in promotional campaigns, but rather efficient investments to ensure that training programs prepare professionals for sectors of the internal market where concrete employment opportunities exist.
I conclude by reiterating the importance of investing in professional training, a symbol of the excellence of our territories.
The world of craft offers a unique potential for employment and a heritage of knowledge, to which the task of sustaining the competitiveness of the European system must be entrusted.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Madam Prime Minister, the European will to establish ambitious objectives in view of the next climate change conference is certainly a commitment to be pursued with tenacity and with the awareness that the results will condition the future of our planet.
