But it is precisely for this reason, dear colleagues, that we must be realistic and more cautious in our expectations.

International preparatory negotiations for the Cancun conference, as far as we know, have not only failed to register appreciable progress toward a global agreement, but have confirmed distrust and resistance regarding the commitments undertaken in Copenhagen.
It has already been mentioned, but I would like to cite China here as well.
China allows itself, for example, an increase in its CO2 emissions of five billion tonnes by the year 2020, with consequences that could be offset.
and perhaps not even, but a compensatory attempt achieved only through a one hundred percent reduction of European industrial emissions by the same year, by two thousand and twenty.

This data not only renders the proposal of an unconditional thirty percent reduction—to which we strongly object—untenable, but leads many independent observers to hypothesize, in any case, a rise, even a significant one, in global emissions by that date.

In this contradictory situation, it would be at the very least imprudent and even demagogic to hypothesize figures and sketch out scenarios that are suggestive but not realistic, where unknowns inevitably reflect on the scale of costs.

The hope is that the European Union will bring to Cancun a shared, realistic, and sustainable proposal, because it is always and in any case preferable an agreement that yields concrete and perceptible results rather than...

expectations inevitably destined to fail and to render, in the eyes of the international public, increasingly less credible—this would indeed be damage difficult to repair—to the efforts of governments on major environmental issues.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I have but one regret in this Chamber tonight as we discuss the Sahrawi people, and that is that we are doing so only because the Moroccans have invaded the refugee camp outside and the Yun. This is a regret for democracy in this Parliament.
Parliament should have independently developed the willingness to discuss this matter, which has been festering for thirty years on international tables.
This is the most relevant political datum.
We were compelled by acts of violence, not because, independently, we decided to enforce human rights.
Why, what is it if not respect for human rights, the fact that there must be a referendum there for self-determination?

It is precisely because Morocco is our friend, because Morocco is a strong element within the relationship, that we must demand forcefully and with all consequent actions that there be a will that is no longer postponable.
We must strive to build the conditions so that the Minuso and Chiuso mission is not solely responsible for creating the conditions for a referendum that is constantly postponed.
We must seek to use all the means at the disposal of the European Union to influence this event and to ensure that that referendum does justice to thirty years of suffering endured by a people.
Mr. President, apart from this matter, I wished to raise a concern with the Presidency.
I believe that someone still does not fully understand what the role of the European Parliament is after the Treaty of Lisbon.

I am compelled to raise a fundamental issue here. The Commissioner for Transport, Callas, repeatedly refuses to meet with the Sky and Space board to discuss the CESAR project, which concerns everyone from an economic, environmental, and safety perspective.

I invite the Presidency to summon Commissioner Callas to the chamber and to explain what program they intend to pursue in this sector, which is both delicate and important for the European Parliament.

Colleagues, the report in question certainly contains positive elements. The general orientation is toward the simplification of procedures and the streamlining of bureaucratic steps for third-country nationals with a regular residence permit in the Member State.

However, just as a point of reflection, I would like to recall that today in Europe tens of millions of citizens, including many young people, are without work due to structural deficiencies in the European production system and as a consequence of a crisis that does not seem to be ending.

Even before considering the citizens of third countries residing in our countries, it is imperative that Europe commit, above all, to implementing economic, political, and social measures that assist our own citizens in finding or regaining employment.
If Europe is able to provide employment for its citizens, it will create solid social foundations for adequately accommodating migratory flows from abroad.
The watchword must be, above all, to make Europe grow on its own feet and with its own strength.
our countries will then have the
Thank you, President. To date, access to employment is regulated only for specific categories of citizens of third countries.
Not all individuals benefit from the general principle of equal treatment in access to employment.

In this context, the European Union must act to ensure fair treatment both for citizens of third countries legally residing within Member States and for beneficiaries of refugee status or of international protection, as per Directive 83 of 29 April 2003.

It is necessary to avoid a growing demand, for example, for seasonal personnel simply because they are paid less or because they have different, lower, costs compared to a European citizen recruited for the same work.

It is necessary to avoid, for example, the risk that many multinational corporations relocate their headquarters to countries such as Morocco or Turkey and send their employees to work in European branches because it is more economical.
For reasons of social justice, ensuring the same treatment for European citizens in terms of remuneration, working conditions, and social security is fundamental.
For this reason, I believe it is just that seasonal workers, those posted, refugees, and self-employed workers be included in this directive.
Making distinctions will become extremely dangerous.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, human trafficking, according to estimates from international organizations and law enforcement agencies, is now the second most lucrative source of profit globally for organized crime, after drug trafficking.
It is estimated that approximately thirty million people are victims of organ trafficking, prostitution, and forced labor.

This means that, first and foremost, the fight against this criminal phenomenon of vast proportions is a battle for the safety of our citizens, against illegality, against the crime that generates crime.
Faced with a phenomenon of this magnitude, Europe must rightly implement drastic measures against those who exploit human beings in various forms.
In the fight against this phenomenon, cooperation between Member States and law enforcement agencies is necessary, but above all, the certainty of punishment for traffickers.

They are exploited because they do not find dignified living conditions in their countries of origin, they live in poverty and despair, and are ready to do anything to leave their homeland for the promise of a better life, a promise that will ultimately not be fulfilled.

Europe, therefore, in addition to preventing crime and protecting victims of trafficking, must commit more fully and with greater care to ensuring that these individuals can find acceptable living conditions in their own countries.
acceptable. Helping them in their own homes must be the guiding principle of European political action, so that our efforts are directed, beyond repression, also towards prevention.

Ecco il testo da tradurre:

"L'analisi dei dati longitudinali presenta sfide uniche rispetto all'analisi dei dati trasversali. In particolare, la presenza di correlazioni seriali all'interno delle misurazioni ripetute per lo stesso individuo richiede l'impiego di tecniche statistiche specifiche per evitare stime distorte dei parametri del modello.

Un problema comune è l'assunzione di indipendenza degli errori, che è violata quando le osservazioni all'interno di un individuo sono correlate. La violazione di questa assunzione può portare a sottostime degli errori standard e a inferenze statistiche errate.

Diverse tecniche sono disponibili per affrontare questo problema, tra cui modelli a effetti misti (mixed-effects models), modelli autoregressivi (autoregressive models) e modelli a compartimenti casuali (random-effects models). La scelta del modello appropriato dipende dalle caratteristiche specifiche dei dati e dalla domanda di ricerca."

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, as Vice President of the Development Committee, I am engaged with the challenges faced by many countries, particularly in the African region, where human rights are routinely violated, trampled upon, if not sometimes even forgotten.

I returned just last Sunday from an official mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo where, in addition to the customary institutional meetings, I made a point of meeting with representatives of NGOs operating in the country and visiting some of the centers where they work.
I met the victims in a country where rape is conceived as a weapon of war, where armed groups continue to
to repeatedly commit mass rapes and other systematic crimes against civil society, particularly against women, the elderly, and children.
I wanted to mention the example of the Democratic Republic of the Congo because it was a very recent experience of mine, as I was saying, extremely recent.
But the appeal I wish to make is generally directed toward the necessity of a strong and continuous condemnation of the brutal violations of women’s rights.
The international community must significantly strengthen funding for initiatives aimed at protecting women from rape and other forms of violence.
violence, including female genital mutilation, even though a severe form of violation of human rights and the physical integrity of women.
The European Heritage Label is of fundamental importance for a continent that encompasses the majority of UNESCO sites and that
Finally, it highlights those natural, archaeological, urban, and culturally significant sites that have played an important role in the history, culture, and integration of the European Union.
The approval of a trademark is an important step in the cohesion process of the Union and is also educational and formative for cultural dialogue.
It can also be observed how this choice bodes well for future generations, who will increasingly possess a shared vision of European heritage that can historically and culturally enrich them.

I thank you for the rapporteur’s efforts and extend my sincere congratulations for the negotiations conducted with the Commission and for the effective success of this initiative, so important for the future of preservation.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's, represent a public health priority for the European Union.
The disease in question has serious repercussions not only for health, but also for those who experience it.
However, the costs incurred for direct and informal care are indeed substantial.
Alzheimer's disease, in fact, does not solely affect those who are afflicted by it, but also involves all those who care for the patients themselves.

Therefore, a European response to the problem is necessary, a global coordination among Member States, a synergy of concerted actions primarily concerning the scientific and research sphere and that addresses the issue.

enhancement of prevention, diagnosis, and refinement of available treatments, including innovative ones, as well as the dissemination of information among States regarding the results achieved within them, increasing the level of knowledge of the disease.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the situation that the Campania region, particularly the city of Naples, has been experiencing for some time is, unfortunately, known to the entire world, and the European Union has had to address the matter on multiple occasions.

Faced with such a situation, now paradoxical in its third-world appearance, I therefore ask the Commission what consequences Italy will face from the perspective of Community law and what economic sanctions may be imposed on Italy should the waste crisis in the countryside not find a definitive solution in the near future.

I would also like to ask whether the Commission can provide detailed data regarding European funds that have been managed by the Campania Region to date for the creation of an integrated waste collection and disposal system.
You see, Commissioner, typically when we discuss an emergency, we refer to dramatic, extreme situations that nevertheless find a solution within a reasonable timeframe.
When a so-called emergency lasts for more than 15 years, evidently something is not working.

The Italian government in recent years has strived to do everything possible to resolve the long-standing issue of waste collection and disposal, but evidently, if today the streets of Naples are inundated with tons of refuse,
tons of waste, the blame is primarily due to the local Campania authorities and their total inability or lack of willingness to work towards finding a solution.

It is clear and beyond any doubt that the conditions in which Naples and the Campania region find themselves are due to the inertia that has characterized, for many years, municipalities, provinces, and regions in the management of the waste cycle.
If differentiated waste collection, the first indispensable element of a functioning waste management plan, is not carried out properly, it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the Italian government has had to dispatch the army—this happened a few weeks ago, but also on previous occasions—to replace hundreds of sudden and simultaneous cases of neotorbism, it evidently cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the emergency has struck Naples, while the rest of Italy fares quite differently—for example, in my region, the Veneto, where differentiated waste collection has been implemented for years without problems and with a very high recycling rate—it means that the responsibility for the emergency rests

on Campania’s politics and local administrators, and above all, on the heavy collusion with organized crime, which has always sought and obtained enormous profits from the waste management business, thanks to the Camorra’s infiltration of politics and local administrations.
Following the lies of the Berlusconi government, which took office in 2008 telling Italians that the waste problem was resolved, the European Union is doing well.
to block funds to Italy until a sustainable waste cycle is presented, based on waste recycling and composting.

And it is certainly not the plan presented by President Caldoro, which once again relies on uncontrolled landfills like those of Chiayano, Taverna del Re, and Terzigno, even within the Parco nazionale del Vesuvio, nor of incinerators that produce death, tumors, or a genuine public health emergency.

Public funds in Campania, during the environmental emergency of these thirteen years, have consolidated criminal relationships between politicians—both left- and right-wing—businesspeople, and the Camorra.

and in environmental matters, solutions are found through the criminalization of dissent, the criminalization of local communities, families, and the land, as the Italian government has done, employing legal loopholes to repress those who defend nature and the territory.

International law defines as a refugee a person who, fearing persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, social affiliation, or political opinion, is outside the country of which they are a citizen.
Cesare Battisti is not a political persecutee.

Despite the protection afforded for years by France, we are discussing a serial killer, perpetrator or instigator of four murders, who has hidden behind the pretext of political struggle to evade a life sentence.
It is shameful for a great country like Brazil to deny the extradition of a criminal who has never repented, by granting him the status of political refugee.
Italian authorities and, above all, the families of the victims demand to see this criminal brought to justice.
Faced with President Lula's intransigence in denying the extradition, the EU cannot leave the Italian government to stand alone.

Europe has and must use all the diplomatic tools at its disposal to ensure that Italy obtains the handover of Battisti, even if it means threatening the suspension of cooperation agreements with Brasilia.
to provide concrete support to the Tunisian people and its transitional government, to revitalize a Euro-Mediterranean dialogue that has been severely neglected in recent years.
The explosion of anger among the young and the poor of the Maghreb and Egypt stems from the inequitable distribution of wealth and limitations on the exercise of fundamental freedoms.

In North Africa, there is a burgeoning and demanding call for more democracy, more economy, more participation, more work, and a look of bewilderment directed at the old European continent, immobile and incapable of grasping the social transformations that have occurred in that area and of developing genuine policies of progress and peace.
Europe should pay more attention to human rights and democracy, foster more dialogue, more collaboration, and more substantive economic interventions.
Europe must open its doors and its heart to North Africa in order to make the Mediterranean a sea of peace.
Enough with the rejection of immigrants and, through the violent collaboration of countries like Libya, more investment, more welcoming initiatives, more aid, more Euro-Mediterranean policy.
History demands it of us.
The resolution approved today by a majority concerning the waste emergency in Campania is a very important signal.
The Campania emergency becomes a European emergency and is a decision in favor of the citizens of Campania.

Opposition is voiced against the expansion of funds that merely serve to consolidate corrupt politicians, unscrupulous entrepreneurs, and the Camorra; support is given to European funds if a credible plan is presented.

No to a waste management plan compatible with the environment, no to uncontrolled landfills in national parks, no to incinerators that produce dioxin, yes instead to recycling and environmentally compatible forms.
and there is also a no to the criminalization of local communities’ dissent, therefore a yes to legality.

It is a significant turning point, a warning for the Berlusconi government and for the regional government led by Caldoro, who until now have done nothing but talk and solidify the fissures and the Mafia bourgeoisie.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the issue of counterfeit medicines is one that is having an increasingly broad impact at both the international and community levels, both due to the increase in the number of cases and the improvement in their sophistication.
It is to these challenges that the Honorable Mattias’ report seeks to respond, the result of lengthy and arduous negotiations.
the report to which we expressed our support defined a regulatory framework that, starting with more precise and detailed definitions, considered
all actors, moments, and resignations of the pharmaceutical supply chain, safety, traceability, obligations for the distribution chain, achieving a good compromise.
These are some of the aspects on which it is necessary to work in order to achieve the primary objective of establishing stricter regulations.
of falsified medicines, leading to a positive and more comprehensive regulatory framework, capable of safeguarding the health of citizens, protecting them from the risk of serious consequences.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, from Egypt, from the virtual square on Facebook to the real one, with millions of people demanding a more equitable distribution of wealth, more justice, protesting against corruption.

From the transition of soldiers and armored vehicles, we must move to genuine democracy, a new Constitution, new elections, abolition of the death penalty, more humane prisons, social rights, and freedoms.
It will be difficult.
Lurking are those who, in the name of an idea, believe in employing any means.
We wish to believe in the marvelous Egyptian people who, however, have never experienced democracy.

We desire a secular democracy, with a clear separation between religious power and political power, a democracy that integrates minorities and realizes genuine rights: public health, social security, work.
Europe should support this path, investing, however, resources capable of fostering genuine development in Egypt – never again dictatorships, never again poverty, never again destitution.
Mr. President, Commissioner, I believe that the issues related to the Mediterranean, with this measure, initiate a phase even more compelling than the actions we have taken.
I believe that the act we are enshrining today is far more important than the regulation itself, or its effects, that of two thousand and six.

I believe this also addresses some limitations of that regulation, which, being unilateral, has led many sectors of fishing to often maintain the idea that, yes, Europe is doing its part, but other coastal countries are not.
I believe it is strategic for us to address the topic in this dimension and with these characteristics.
The work carried out by my colleague Rivellini, which has been widely appreciated, deserves, I believe, a formal acknowledgment in this setting.
Nevertheless, I have a distinct feeling that the fact we are unable to resolve this issue in the first reading means we will proceed to the second reading.
particularly regarding the interpretation of Article 28 of this regulation, raises a question. The Parliament, on this occasion, aligns itself with the Commission.

that is, Parliament essentially states that it is desirable for these delegated acts to be the responsibility of the Commission; there is, incidentally, some resistance from the Council, and the absence today is also a significant one.

But this act ensures that the idea is ripe within Parliament that maintaining biodiversity, maintaining the fish stocks of this important sea, that this operation too, represents the future of the fishermen.
But having said that, I believe that the phase we face must once again place the idea of codecision centrally.
These delegated acts have a reason for being delegated and therefore conferred today upon the Commission, but international agreements must maintain a firm role for Parliament when they occur.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, in my opinion we have two problems in this matter: one concerning the method, and the other concerning the substance.

The matter of method is that we are proceeding through an expedient for which we thank Honorable Fraga, namely the oral question, to discuss something that should, instead, after the Treaty of Lisbon, be a right of this Parliament.
I believe this practice must end; we cannot resort to a strategy to accompany a co-decision process.
Codecision occurs when it is nurtured in the phases in which it ripens.
Today we are holding this debate; the treaty concludes, and it will proceed, and we will say yes or no at the end.
Well, this method needs to be reconceptualized.

Regarding this matter, however, I simply wished to emphasize, while concurring with many of my colleagues’ points, the measurement of the effects of fishing agreements, to ensure they are not merely commercial agreements through which we purchase cephalopods in Mauritania at one euro per kilogram.

These must be able to measure both sustainability but, above all, the impact on that country’s economy, to understand how many employed individuals are affected, to understand what the rate of innovation is for artisanal fishing, to understand the utilization of these resources.
not merely a pure and simple commercial exchange, but a fishing agreement, with all its implications.
President, the favorable vote expressed for the report by the Honourable Rivasi is the result of an assessment of the management of the H1N1 influenza.
2009001, which is 20090010, aims to establish general conduct criteria valid in any future global health emergency situations.
The report, following a lengthy and positive phase of revision, establishes cooperation, independence, and transparency as its principal pillars.

It aspires to greater and improved cooperation between the health authorities of the Member States and European institutions, in order to be able to develop a harmonized and common risk management approach.
The objectives are to assess the strategies of the Member States regarding national influenza management plans, including vaccine stockpiles, and the publication of names of…
all experts consulted by European health authorities and an efficient relationship of trust with the media tasked with disseminating public health messages.
That is why it received our favorable vote.

Mr. President, Mr. President, until today, the recommendations adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean have been incorporated into Community legislation provisionally, through annual fishing opportunities regulations.
These concern conservation, management, exploitation, control, and marketing measures for fishery products and farmed aquatic resources in the Mediterranean.
The permanent nature of such recommendations, however, necessitates a more stable legal instrument for their incorporation into Community law.
It is therefore appropriate to incorporate the recommendations in question through a single legislative act to which future recommendations may be added.
Today we have done this, and it will improve legal certainty, while also constituting an important step towards simplification.
At this point, the contracting parties of the CGMPM are obligated to ensure full implementation of the measures agreed upon, effective from the date established.
Timely transposition was therefore necessary in order to render such measures directly applicable to natural or legal persons at the Community level and to ensure legal certainty.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I believe that the approval of the report by my colleague Podimata represents a significant step forward for a more balanced, more advanced, and stronger economic and fiscal policy within Europe.

It is now evident to all the urgency of equipping ourselves, as Europe, as a coordination between the twenty-seven countries, with economic and financial instruments capable of governing the economy and not merely being subjected to it.
For this reason, the proposal to tax financial transactions has garnered considerable resonance, substantial discussion, and significant attention.

The fact that the majority of this Parliament voted for this provision is an important and significant matter, because for the first time, it did not let the opportunity pass and instead took a step forward.
I hope that the Commission and the Council will continue along this path.
Madam President, I welcome the reports on gender equality and female poverty in Europe and I am pleased that they have been discussed today, which marks the centenary of International Women’s Day.

Despite Directive 2002-73 concerning equal opportunities for men and women in access to employment, vocational training and professional advancement and in working conditions, further efforts must still be made to achieve proper implementation.

Consider that, despite the significant increase in female education levels in recent years and the fact that the number of female graduates now exceeds that of male graduates, women remain concentrated in traditionally female sectors, often those with lower pay, and occupy fewer leadership positions across all spheres of society.
The lack of access to care services for dependents such as children, disabled individuals, and the elderly, to adequate leave arrangements, and to flexible work options prevents women from working.

I would like to conclude by remembering the women around the world who are fighting for the most basic rights, and I would like our Assembly to express solidarity with the Iranian feminist associations that are taking to the streets today, encouraging women to protest without the IJA.
As all colleagues who have spoken have done, we are finally returning to discussion, and I hope we return to action soon, with specific choices regarding economic policy and common industrial policy.
Thanks to the Lange report, the excellent work done by the colleague, and the communication from President Tajani.

This choice implies several important aspects. First, the relaunch and recovery, as stated, of the European economy and the stability of employment also, and perhaps above all, lie in revival and support worldwide.
manufacturing sector, to the most advanced sectors and to those even traditional, because there lies a frontier that can still be tackled and was not so obvious until recently.

Secondly, the recovery of industrial sectors in Europe also means that our competitiveness is not determined in the sectors of finance and services, but here still, and it is not too late for us to do so. We can aim for a challenge for Europe to regain competitiveness with the rest of the world in industrial sectors.

Thirdly, it has been stated that the new industrial policy focuses on factors rather than sectors, focusing on the factors and instruments that can genuinely foster new enterprises and new resilience and capacity for updating.

Therefore, I believe it is important to highlight, as has been done, these new factors on which action must be taken: credit. We urge new initiatives, in addition to those already announced by the Commissioner on the topic of credit, raw materials, and energy costs.

innovation, research, the need to strengthen in Europe the capacity to transfer technological results of research and innovation within enterprises, into new products, and into new modes of organizing production.

We must leverage a very distinctive fabric within our Europe, and in certain countries in particular, that of SMEs, the quality of businesses, the quality of products, and, overall, the uniqueness of industry in Europe.
and I believe that we should rediscover them, these manufacturing traditions, these manufacturing roots in many countries, in order to renew and transform them.
Finally, the topic of territory, which is very important.
European policies succeed when they intersect with and find a territory capable of addressing them.
Therefore, thanks to Lange, and we hope for excellent collaboration with the Commission to achieve concrete results in a timely manner.
Many milestones have been achieved, but some battles remain to be fought.
Today, the urgency concerns women of other cultures living in Europe and throughout the world, in contexts where it is difficult for them to assert minimal standards of dignity and humanity.

We cannot celebrate this occasion without placing the question of women in the Arab Muslim world at its center; otherwise, we continue to ignore a problem that today concerns them but will soon become ours as well.
We cannot ignore the emergency figures that grow year after year, even in Europe, in our cities, in the schools where our children grow.
For some time, cases of violence of all kinds experienced by Muslim women within their own families have been on the rise.

For this reason, I have been asking for some time, and I reiterate today, that Europe implement targeted policies against the spread of Islamic radicalism, forced marriages, honor killings, female genital mutilation, and domestic violence.
We, European women and men, must fight for those women who live in Europe, but not only that, who have no voice and are oppressed by the monster of Islamic integrationism.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I voted in favor of the resolution on Turkey because the constitutional reform, which occurred last December, has been unanimously recognized as a significant step taken by Turkey towards Europe.
Naturally, there are still many steps to be taken, and I express concern in this regard over the numerous arrests of journalists.

I emphasize that Turkey is the European Union’s seventh trading partner and that the European Union is Turkey’s primary trading partner, and that trade exchanges, correctly interpreted for centuries, have fostered mutual understanding and peaceful coexistence among peoples.

I therefore applaud the notable progress made in promoting connections between the European Union and Turkey, particularly those through the motorways of the sea traversing the northern Adriatic and northern Tyrrhenian Seas.
on which an annual flow of over 250,000 semi-trailers now moves in both directions, in connection with a significant rail-truck-container-wagon link from the port to inland European destinations.
In this way, a considerable volume of truck traffic on roads has been eliminated, and I hope that progress continues along that path.
Mr. President, with today's vote, we have given a further impetus to the definitive solution of this problem, but we have not voted for the best possible solution.

Indeed, I wish to recall that the over 300 amendments presented to the report were transformed into 38 compromise amendments, all adopted, which serve to better define the priority sectors of the strategy, as well as the objectives of this strategy.

The Commission, with its permanent task force, must ensure the collection and dissemination of statistical data and best practices, and Member States should appoint a senior government official, we hope, to serve as a contact point for the implementation of the strategy.
But we could have been even more forceful and less hypocritical if, in the report, we had emphasized the obligations and duties that the Roma community should still respect in the host countries.
This is my hope, that is to say, that solutions are found soon that allow for a better coexistence of this community in all Member States.
Lampedusa has been overrun by tens of thousands of North Africans whom the island could never conceivably accommodate.
Italy has been targeted for weeks by hundreds of clandestine balconies.
And if we do not all react together, if the EU does not react, the wave of people fleeing will continue.
The clandestine arrivals of recent months must be returned home; there is no alternative.
But the Italian government, beyond some words of solidarity, has been left to manage this biblical exodus of unpredictable dimensions alone. Where is Europe?
Until today, Brussels has been overwhelmingly absent, exhibiting a shameful behavior that my fellow citizens can no longer tolerate.
Europe has left Italy alone to face an unprecedented emergency.

Instead, Europe must not only assist Italy in the repatriation of undocumented migrants, but must also support the Italian government's efforts to prevent further departures, particularly from Tunisia, of thousands and thousands of people.

Quite a different matter applies to Libyan refugees, regarding whom Europe must stand alongside Italy in cleansing and logistical management operations, but above all, must commit to ensuring that refugees are hosted in all member states.
The reception of those fleeing from war cannot fall solely on Italy.
It is time to stop the talk.
The European Union, if it exists, should make its presence felt.
We cannot tolerate Italy filling up with undocumented migrants while France repels them with shameful methods.
Irregular migrants must be returned to their countries of origin, while all Member States must commit, from now on, to receiving Libyan refugees.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the matter of forecasting adequate financial resources to guarantee the decommissioning processes of nuclear power plants is an issue already addressed by the
European Union legislation on nuclear safety is now of great relevance, particularly in light of recent international events and the resulting decisions of Union governments regarding the matter.

The work of the Honourable Marinescu, to which we have expressed our support, addresses the specific cases of certain countries that, at the time of their accession, undertook particular obligations regarding the decommissioning of nuclear facilities and which, precisely for this activity, received special support from the European Union.
Beyond specific cases, it is essential to establish an effective verification and examination control of nuclear power plants located within the territory of the Union.
It appears, indeed, that the number of reactors estimated to be decommissioned in the near future within the European Community is considerable.

It will therefore be essential to ensure guarantee mechanisms, even and especially in these cases, for the earmarking of adequate financial resources necessary to address both routine and extraordinary needs.
I would also like to thank the speaker.
The report addresses the developments that have occurred in changes to control and communication systems.
Even from this, a picture of considerable heterogeneity emerges, particularly among the States in the communication of irregularities and fraud.
The report repeatedly highlights the anomaly of low levels of fraud and irregularities reported by several countries regarding agricultural expenditure, structural funds, and pre-accession funds.
It is truly necessary to clarify the statistical data that have been submitted.
The situation is further complicated by the backlog, a consequence of ineffective recovery efforts.
However, one fact emerges clearly and confirms a long-term trend.

The fight for legality and transparency in the spending of European resources, such as combating fraud and tax evasion, cannot yet rely on the full collaboration of states and governments alongside European institutions.

In this sense, I believe the proposals put forward in a review of Community legislation on public procurement to be appropriate, as is the need for what I term a European public register of beneficiaries of Community funds.
I thank the speakers and also Commissioner Barnier for his great availability towards Parliament.
We advocate for the idea of a single market capable of understanding and satisfying social expectations and the implications that social dimension entails.
It is not a utopia, it is realism and modernity as well.

It is indeed this vision that makes the market itself stronger, because economicism alone—essentially, the reduction of the market to economicism—has demonstrated how this does not resolve either the problems of growth or those of cohesion.
It is, in essence, a matter of fully realizing, here and now, the entirely European idea of a social market economy.
In today's texts, this is present.
There is recognition of social enterprises, cooperatives, their role, mutual societies, foundations, ten percent of European businesses, and a significant portion of our employment.
they are entities that are veritable companies, a demonstration of economic pluralism and a pluralism of enterprises.

They work with capital but not for capital, and they seek to realize labor, welfare, quality, and social innovation, demonstrating that these values must and can be part of the internal market in Europe.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the justification offered by Beijing that the artist Ai Weiwei was arrested for economic offenses does not persuade; neither does the explanation that such persecution is being directed toward a free and dissident artist.
It does not convince, as this arrest is situated within hundreds of arrests of opponents and the systematic repression against all dissent.

In the days when the Arab uprisings erupt, our thoughts turn to the image of cruel violence in Tiananmen Square against the young Chinese who demanded, as they do today with the Gersomino revolution, freedom and democracy.

China has opened itself to the West on an economic level, yet without reconciling production with environmental protection and worker safety, and it fails to achieve any openness toward democracy and pluralism.

Our actions do not constitute interference in China’s internal affairs, as Beijing claims, but rather a response to the appeals of men and women, of movements, of parties who intend to build a world free from intolerance on every continent.
The government in Beijing should observe what is happening in the world to understand whether, if it does not change, it will be historical events and Chinese citizens who will change China.
Please.

This represents the direct assessment of the impact on SMEs, within the triumphant Lisbon Programme initially and subsequently the Fotocopia Europa 2020 strategy, on which resources are even being considered for allocation from the next multiannual financial framework 2014-2020.

I can therefore do no more than reiterate what thousands of European citizens and taxpayers are asking: what is the purpose of Europe if it is unable to solve the continent’s economic problems, speak with a single voice on foreign policy matters, and squander money?
I hope that what Commissioner Tajani has repeatedly stated will come to fruition.
I hope that the revision of the SME Code is truly capable of simplifying bureaucracy, ensuring access to credit recovery, and facilitating internationalization.
With the directive on late payments, a concrete and genuine milestone has been achieved, a result of political will and not Europropaganda.

If the costs of yet another financial strategy will once again fund only empty words, I urge the European institutions to make amends to the dozens of small business owners in my region, the Veneto, who took their own lives before witnessing the failure of their small enterprise.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, while Europe turns a blind eye, the Europol report of 2011 on organized crime states that with the accession of Romania and Bulgaria to Schengen, powerful Turkish, Russian, and Albanian criminal organizations will be able to expand their operations throughout Europe.
Again, I quote verbatim: Turkey’s illegal immigration will extend to the Bulgarian coast, and drug and human trafficking in the hands of Turkish-Albanian organized crime will increase.

Regarding human trafficking, the entry into Schengen of Romania and Bulgaria could offer Bulgarian organized crime and emerging Roma communities new opportunities to expand their already substantial trafficking activities across the rest of Europe.
Ultimately, increased illegal immigration from Turkey, drug trafficking, and human trafficking mean less security for European citizens.
Europe wants to do a great favor to organized crime.
The Northern League party will always oppose this kind of egregious choice.
Whoever votes in favor of this report tomorrow will bear the responsibility for a vote that will open a highway for organized crime, leading directly to the heart of Europe.
Thanks to the Treaty of Amsterdam, environmental policy and sustainability policy gained greater relevance, and sustainability policy became more important.
The focus has been on the integration between economic and environmental policy, and on the inclusion of environmental issues within policies and other sectors.

Key sectors include climate change, sustainable transport, nature and biodiversity, health and environment, as well as the use of natural resources and waste management, and the international dimension of sustainable development.
In June 2006, the European Council, in its conclusion, invited the Union and its Member States to extend national accounts to the fundamental aspects of sustainable development.
National accounts must therefore be supplemented by an integrated economic and environmental accounting system, suitable for providing fully consistent data.
I voted in favor of this draft regulation because it creates new uses for national accounting data, environmental statistics, and other statistical sectors.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, my favorable vote on the Garriga report concerning the Union's forthcoming financial perspectives stems from the conviction that precisely during one of the moments of greatest crisis
Regarding what is termed the European spirit, it is decisive to insist and prevail in ensuring credible instruments are given to the Union, beginning with an adequate financial endowment.

Therefore, the request for an additional five [million/billion – context dependent] in the next budget is a just and necessary request, perhaps not sufficient, but indispensable to provide answers to the major issues before us.
to address real problems such as greater regional cohesion, increased research and innovation capacity, a stronger ability to generate growth, and to offer employment.

adequate, none of these problems will find a sufficient answer, starting with the introduction of this intermediate category into cohesion policy, which only makes sense if it does not cause damage to the other existing categories.
That is why I voted in favor, and I hope that the Commission and the Council will follow the recommendations of this report.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the new Hungarian Constitution reduces the possibility of intervention by oversight bodies such as the Constitutional Court and increases the powers of the executive branch, thereby challenging the ordinary balance of powers.
Social rights are undermined as the State provides assistance to those in need only if they agree to perform public service work.
The right to self-defense is explicitly sanctioned, permitting the possession of firearms at home even without a license.
Abortion rights are prohibited, and strongly discriminatory rules are introduced against homosexuals.
All of this is contrary to Directive number seventy-eight two thousand, which establishes a general framework for combating discrimination.

I therefore ask the Commissioner how she intends to intervene, considering that the fundamental rights of the new Hungarian Constitution are scarcely compatible with those of the European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
We are about to vote on a strategically significant document that offers the negotiation on post-2020 financial perspectives a robust framework.

Starting from the request for coherence between objectives and instruments, between the new role that European institutions are called upon to play after Lisbon and in the face of the recession, and the resources that we collectively decide to invest.
This consistency also implies a serious response to the demand for innovation emerging from public opinion, the recipients of EU policies, and European social and productive forces.
We did it for cohesion, a crucial chapter for deciding what we want and what the European Union will be in the coming years.
it tells us that cohesion is today a vital hub of the European project, an important asset for all to safeguard, to protect, to renew.
Particularly critical on this front is the effort to introduce an intermediate category of regions, especially because in several cases the years of recession we have experienced have
exacerbated internal disparities, rendering even more important efficient and adequate support for the less developed regions of Europe, combating waste and clearly outlining the development policy.
However, I believe that the challenge of intermediate categories with a safeguard clause is a challenge that we must accept to open a new phase in politics.
of cohesion in Europe and also to substantiate the cohesion policy with that more balanced, more sustainable development that we want to guarantee for Europe in the coming years.
I too join in thanking the Honorable Langen and the other colleagues with whom we worked to finalize this complex report.
I believe what the honourable member recalled is particularly important.
Langen, when he stated that we want to maintain the purpose, the scope of this regulation, remaining faithful to what was the mandate of the G-20 in Pittsburgh in 2009.
The fundamental objective is to bring the majority of over-the-counter derivatives onto regulated platforms to avoid continued exposure to a high degree of

risk and speculation. When one arrives, as has happened, at exchanging, at insuring four hundred million dollars without collateral, that is, without adequate reserves, one understands what risks we run.

Having said that, however, I would also like to mention two problems: the first problem is the relationship with the Council, the second problem is the cohesiveness of the proposed reform of financial markets that we must pursue.

I raise the first issue concerning the Council, and I say this very clearly: the feeling is that too often the Council represents an obstacle to acting swiftly and effectively on the financial markets reform front.
I hope that the new Presidency will take on this issue, because even on this occasion we must put
I anticipate a lengthening of timelines largely attributable to the positions, difficulties, and conflicts that emerge during Council proceedings.
It is a problem that concerns the procedure we intend to follow.
The second matter concerns the organic nature and specificity of the measures.
There is not only the measure regarding OTCs, there is also the measure regarding short selling and other matters.

I wish to draw attention to two specific points: the particular issue of the commodities market, a market that requires specific anti-speculative interventions, and the problem of local authorities’ exposure to derivatives within the European Union.
I believe that these are issues on which Parliament must intervene.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the Fukushima incident continues to produce very serious consequences, with the release of seawater and radioactive water six hundred and fifty times greater than legal limits.
The risk that food products become contaminated is high.
Europe has established very strict controls, but this applies exclusively to fresh produce.
No protective regulations have been issued for processed products, particularly canned fish.
We import three hundred seventy zero tonnes of canned tuna, and our primary suppliers are the countries of Southeast Asia, which import fish from Japan.
This means that canned fish imported into Europe could contain Japanese fish.
It is fundamental and urgent to provide precise information regarding the place of origin.
Today, consumers know where the box was produced, but not the location where the fish was caught.

The Commission has recently acknowledged this and intends to fill this gap with the reform of the common fisheries policy, which, however, will not come into effect before two years, just as the Sommer report, currently under discussion in this plenary session, will not have effect for three years.
We must not create alarmism, but consumers have the right to urgent and transparent information.
The Commission must intervene as soon as possible.
Mr. President Tusk, your address gives us cause for optimism; we hope that the Polish Presidency will be a contribution to the fight against the Europe of egoisms.
national, without looking to the future, which might be a contribution in favor of a Europe that truly thinks of itself as an integrated reality with a common destiny.
But, as you rightly stated in your address, a Presidency has concrete problems to face and resolve.
I wish to indicate to you, in this brief time, two crucial issues concerning the economic and financial crisis.
First issue: the reform of financial markets.

It is not a technical problem; it is a major democratic issue of our time. The timelines are too long; it is necessary to resolve issues such as those relating to the reform of short selling and OTC transactions.
Secondly, we are confronted with the issue of financial transaction taxation; we need to examine this matter closely, and we expect a concrete contribution from the Polish Presidency in this regard.
More than twenty years have passed since the signing of the Schengen Agreements.
No one questions the advantages of free movement, but it must be acknowledged that the current arrangement is no longer adequate for present and future needs.

Therefore, Member States and the EU as a whole must commit to reviewing the operational mechanisms of Schengen, ensuring that freedom of movement does not compromise the legitimate security needs of our citizens.

As far as we know to date, the Commission’s orientations may also be partly shared, particularly regarding the introduction of a mechanism that allows States to temporarily reinstate border controls in the event of an emergency.
However, it is necessary to see how this will occur and whether the declarations will be followed by actions, particularly concrete results.

Certainly, it will also be necessary to undertake a general reform of the European border protection system, particularly its external borders, on which Frontex must as soon as possible become an agency with genuine powers of intervention and support for national authorities.
We must protect our external borders if we want to continue with this Schengen.
It is time for courageous choices in this Europe if one does not wish merely to survive.

The crisis has profoundly marked the lives of European citizens and businesses and risks, if we do not react, irreversibly lowering social and cultural quality, well-being, and the future of young people and Europeans.

Forget about values of cohesion and prosperity; emerging from the crisis means creating remedies for the identified causes, remedies against speculation, to which, if necessary, we must also clip the nails, imposing strict rules on financial markets.

remedies against recession, remedies against a development model that has placed the individual below profit, remedies against the resurgent nationalism that prevents Europe from making the choices that today belong to it.

Above all, it is time to define the tools, the resources, even new ones, to move forward, to ignite the engines of growth, through research, innovation, training, support for productive investments, infrastructure, and employment, because without work, people are without dignity and without rights.
This report, thanks to Pervance Beres and colleagues, indicates a possible strategy for a Europe proud and aware of its role.
To European leadership, if it exists, now it falls to them to implement it.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, behind the widespread prosperity of our continent lies a hidden Europe, often invisible, of which we speak in terms of numbers, statistics, and sociology, rather than as flesh-and-blood people, often women and children or the elderly—that is, the most vulnerable population.
But Europe will not be credible with its citizens if it does not learn to be consistent, and we here want to be consistent in this Parliament, at this stage of Europe's life.

If we say we are founding the Union on values, on human rights, I don't believe we can abruptly halt or severely curtail a program for those who are hungry, for those who lack the right to food, access to food.

fundamental, for an unresolved legal matter, is agricultural land, it is social land, and if it is to be social, Madam Commissioner, that it not come at the expense of other social programs, but be a new, ad hoc fund, with appropriate resources.
Let us say we want to guarantee food safety for Europeans, but the primary right to security is to have it, food, and then for it to be healthy.
Therefore, here is our coherence and our commitment.
Therefore, a legal solution must be found that ensures continuity and, with the assistance of non-governmental organizations and volunteer work, guarantees the fundamental human right, that to food.
Mr. President, solely to support this report and highlight two aspects in particular—one because it fits into the debate currently underway on the
review of the common fisheries policy and on the reference option, which is linked to the regionalization of a policy that, in recent years, has demonstrated its weakness due to centralization.
This phase of regionalization finds a particular application in the Black Sea.
I believe that the elements contained in colleague Iotova's report describe a specific situation, but the situation in the Adriatic Sea is not dissimilar and could be replicated elsewhere in Europe.
of the Tyrrhenian or Aegean Sea, that is, interactions primarily between European and extra-European fishing are interactions often very damaging to European markets and European consumers.
The second matter I would like to highlight briefly is that of referencing a common Coast Guard.
There is no politics if there is no exercise of control.

Checks today are carried out by disparate forces across Europe. I believe it is time to understand how one of the first European law enforcement agencies, namely the coast guard, could have common management, greater correlation, and, why not, a single European body.
With this hope, I fully support the contents of the report by colleague Iotova.

Thank you, Mr. President. The disaster that struck the Gulf of Mexico more than a year ago has prompted the European Commission to reflect on the legislation related to the activity of offshore oil platforms.
Even the European Parliament, with this report, wished to express its position on the matter, approving a text that requires adequate technical and financial capabilities.
for sector operators and aims to establish high safety standards, thereby solidifying the European Union’s leading role in promoting the safety of offshore activities.
The new measures on the matter requested from the Commission must focus on international coordination and a realistic approach that combines all existing excellences.
within the sector at the procedural level and avoids the creation of new bodies or additional bureaucracy that would risk diverting attention from achieving concrete final objectives.

The report, in concrete terms, in addition to greater accountability for operating companies, requires improvements to communication and information and knowledge sharing mechanisms and advocates for the strengthening and expansion of the role and competencies of the European Maritime Safety Agency.
It is for all these reasons that I consider the achieved result positive, thanks to the negotiation on this text to which we have expressed our support.
I thank my colleagues Zeber and Schilakakis, and I also thank Commissioner Edegard.

I believe that we are gathered here today to discuss and deliberate in order to genuinely achieve a robust European climate policy, capable of safeguarding economic development and the well-being of European citizens.
International climate policies, as has been recalled thus far, have primarily focused on the reduction of CO2 emissions.
The proposal highlights how we must also address the fight against other anthropogenic emissions that cause the formation of tropospheric ozone, impacting climate change.

Many things have already been recalled that I believe it is right for us to keep firmly in mind today; we are able to do so with absolutely reasonable costs, we have the technologies at our disposal, and although it is undeniable that CO2 emissions are primarily impactful.

Although it is undeniable that the other greenhouse gases present in the atmosphere are present in a much smaller percentage, it is undeniable that their potential is very high and that we can therefore achieve significant results within a few years, within a few decades.
important.
There are signs, it was also recalled by the United States, I saw a study that was published in Nature directly by the scientific agency of the U.S. Department of Commerce with which I…

I believe there are many points of contact with respect to the analysis conducted by our colleagues, and therefore I imagine these will also be factors that will allow Europe to present itself at Durban with an even stronger, more concrete, and more significant position.

I will conclude simply by remembering, as has already been recalled, that for this extraordinarily difficult and delicate moment we are living through, we have been discussing homelessness just minutes ago, and there is a sensitivity among European citizens that we must take into account, and therefore, considering the large…

Regarding sensitivity, of course, and concerning employment, we should be able to conduct a communication campaign that clearly explains to citizens what we concretely intend to do in terms of development, their well-being, and the protection of jobs.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, the single market, the free movement, the Treaty of Lisbon are all elements that have intervened irrespective of a modification of our way of legislating, the European way and the national way.

It is necessary to follow up on the commitments that have arisen from these occasions; in particular, a genuine phase of simplification of the legislative system must be initiated, a simplification phase that should foster a different dialogue between Europe and individual States.

I would start directly with our documents, and I take this opportunity to suggest a kind of clarity test for our documents. When we produce a white paper, a green paper, it must all be more comprehensible.

May this virtuous phase of legislative initiation involve assigning a specific delegation to a European Commissioner tasked specifically with clarifying the legislation and the relationship between the Member States and Europe itself.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, esteemed representative of the Council, and Madam Commissioner, first and foremost, I too would like to positively acknowledge, as other colleagues have done, the anti-corruption package approved by the European Commission last June sixth.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon, and measures of a European scale are necessary to combat it.
The vast majority of our European citizens, according to Eurobarometer estimates, believe that Europe must do more.
How could one fault them?

In many Member States, the political will to counter corruption has been lacking—consider that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

If we consider the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, citizens' rights, and trust in the rule of law, it is clear that national measures to combat it, adopted to date by Member States, are insufficient to contain a phenomenon in expansion.

It is the European Union that must provide a unified and strong response, especially now, at the height of an unprecedented economic crisis, which is impacting the lives of citizens, the stability of welfare systems, and the ability of institutions to guarantee essential services.
Corruption causes the loss of one hundred twenty billion euros every year, equivalent to 1% of the European Union’s GDP, and daily diverts resources of the Union and its Member States that
they could be utilized to provide essential services—education, early childhood care, employment, transportation—in short, to divert clean resources to support individuals.

Therefore, it is necessary to demonstrate greater courage and greater resolve, both in overseeing the implementation of anti-corruption measures and in intensifying and strengthening measures to combat corruption at the Union level.

Specifically, we cannot speak of fighting corruption if we are not capable of adopting at least minimal norms for the definition of the crime of corruption, of which there is no trace in the package just approved.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters for measuring the extent of the phenomenon in Member States, essential for preparing an effective response.
We are, for example, in favor of revitalizing the EU network of contact points against corruption, as proposed by the resolution we will vote on tomorrow.
The crisis is not recent; it has existed for several years.
Perhaps the time has come to undertake a critical assessment of the policies followed thus far. Has everything always been done correctly?
We have always conducted appropriate analyses of the situation.
the right approach was chosen
The very European Central Bank, which, as Minister Rostovky says, saved Europe, has it always also done well when, fearing inflation, it raised interest rates?
President Barroso identifies a problem: the speed of the markets and the slowness of policy. But is this the only problem?

Certainly, if one considers that we are still at the implementation stage of July 21st, this should at least suggest better preparation and organization of summits and their conclusions, but politics will always be slower than the markets.
Then the point is to look further ahead, to shift the emphasis onto the fight against unemployment and development.

This is the ground that the European Commission must choose. Even today, in President Barroso’s speech, there was more concreteness regarding the deficit and less on indications of growth and development.

The Commission should move beyond its weakness, stating that the priority is the fight against unemployment and job creation, redistribution of wealth, and a public investment strategy, also changing the rules of the new European Stability Pact.
Mr. President, I believe that the challenge of the coming years is to ensure that Europe, as has been said, maintains its previous primacy.
a world-renowned tourist destination while also being able to enhance, both in terms of environmental preservation and competitive capacity, its entire territorial heritage.

It is a challenging and non-trivial undertaking, even considering not only the opportunities but also the aggressiveness of other countries in this sector, from other continents, from China to India to Brazil.
Now, within this framework, the Commissioner Tajani recalled, it becomes fundamental, as also noted in the opinion of the committee that we approved in the regional development committee,
to maintain a robust overarching strategy for the entire European Union regarding tourism, alongside a recognition of the role of regions and territories.
In this sense, full engagement is essential from the outset, in compliance with the principle of subsidiarity of the regions and local authorities.
Furthermore, I believe that the development of integrated tourism networks and projects should be encouraged, starting with the creation of partnerships for the exchange of best practices.
It seems right to me, also, the proposal to identify a Europe brand capable of defining a high quality of the tourist product.
Naturally, it will be up to the Commission to better define the priorities, particularly from a financial perspective, to ensure that this primacy of Europe is maintained in the future.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, the preparation of a common strategic framework for the financing of research and innovation constitutes one of the greatest opportunities that European development and the European economy have before them.

It involves acting upon the lever that can genuinely trigger a moment of growth and also of new qualified employment, such as that of researchers and young people who dedicate themselves to new opportunities in innovation, technology, and related professions.
One observation, above all, that emerges from this work is that we must increasingly emphasize in Europe research and innovation that lead to practical application.
to foster new enterprises that result in new patents and that do not remain purely basic research, purely important knowledge, yes, but not sufficient to truly trigger the ascent of development.

The second observation concerns the relationship with local authorities, regions, and territories, which are also an important tool for programming on the ground and for facilitating interaction between research, universities, centers of excellence, and businesses.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, the European Schools were established with the aim of ensuring access to education in one’s mother tongue for the children of agents of the European institutions required to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of their country of origin.
The first European school was established in Luxembourg as far back as 1953 on the initiative of a group of officials.
Over the years, considering the positive impact of this form of teaching, fourteen European Schools have been established within the various Member States.

While acknowledging that the European Schools system represents a necessity rather than a luxury, it is evident that, more than fifty years after the creation of the first European School, such a system may present obsolete aspects and must, in some way, be adapted and tailored to new economic and social needs.

I have therefore expressed my favorable vote for the text proposed by colleague Cavada, which aspires to greater involvement of the European Union to support and coordinate the actions of the Member States, called upon to work towards developing and improving the system of European Schools.
It is known that investing in education means investing in the future of our young Europeans.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, over the past decades, there has been an exponential increase in the number of natural disasters that have caused the deaths of tens of thousands of people in various parts of the world.
Last year, within the Development Committee, I followed the work on the report concerning the European Union's capacity to respond to disasters.
It has emerged how much more remained to be done to ensure a coordinated response from the European Union in the face of the multiplication of earthquakes, floods, and tsunamis.
The European Union’s response to the earthquake in Haiti, for example, clearly demonstrated the complexity of the existing instruments and procedures.

Although the Member States and Community institutions acted promptly in terms of sending humanitarian aid, the management of the crisis raised a number of issues regarding efficiency, coordination, and transparency.

Precisely for this reason, I expressed a favorable vote for the text presented by my colleague Elisabetta Gardini, which envisions greater efficiency in all phases of disaster management and enhanced coordination.
Among the parties involved, this is a simplification intended to avoid unnecessary overlap and time wastage that would hinder the provision of rapid and effective assistance.
It is merely a commendable initiative; I believe it will involve constructing, rather, a European policy towards tourism.
The European brand is a good idea, but I want to dwell on two points. There is no seaside or coastal tourism without a policy of coastal planning.

I believe that the time has come for Europe, precisely to protect this important sector, to produce an initiative in which the conception of the sea and the conception of the coast are not limited to a form of urban planning that ends at the high-water mark and does not comprehensively involve the sea.
I believe that an integrated policy in this sense is useful, as it will be necessary to construct everything that lies behind the claims of rural tourism. Rural tourism can be
an excellent source of income for disadvantaged areas, for areas where work no longer exists, where it is important to prevent further depopulation and ensure human settlement.

Well, it’s not enough merely to make assertions there; rather, one should suggest to Europe and to individual states that they intervene regarding the fiscal levy. Promoting tourism in rural areas might mean paying lower taxes, and perhaps in this way a genuine opportunity can truly be built for the tourism resource and for those who reside there.
Thank you, Mr. President. I wish to express my congratulations on the work done by the Honorable Fidanza, which logically fits within the framework of these actions.
initiatives and actions undertaken at the community level in the field of tourism, following the assignment of new competencies to the EU by the Treaty of Lisbon.
I share and wish to emphasize the affirmation of the importance of a Europe with a unitary destination for certified and quality tourism and the willingness to promote this.
the same idea, translating it into actions at the level of structures, allocation of resources, funding, and coordination of actions between the various levels of government of the Union's countries.

an approach to be valued and rewarded, given that the sector in question, with its implications in terms of percentage of GDP generated, employment, and new opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises,
Enterprises, attention to the protection and enhancement of the environment is able to develop and therefore to respond to the main challenges posed by contemporary issues.
For all these reasons, I consider this report positive, an important signal in the direction of promoting a European tourism policy.
Mr. President, even for restoration, three small considerations—we need more Europe here as well.
I believe it is inevitable that on certain subjects there will be a genuine attitude in which not only is it hoped for, but more Europe is actively built.
More Europe means, for example, genuinely beginning to consider a common highway patrol, identical rules from the perspective of safety protection.
More Europe means having a European education policy, not simply delegating this to individual states, but building a genuine education policy, for example.
Regarding schools, regarding young people, and regarding categories somewhat more at risk—I mentioned motorcyclists a moment ago, but we can also speak of truck drivers.
More Europe means having common tools within the machinery to improve safety conditions.
I believe they are a targeted strategy to be developed with automotive companies and European vehicle production.
Well, I believe that if all of this falls within the framework of a common policy, I genuinely think that perhaps conditions will improve.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, this report addresses the issue of global food security. Global signifies that this issue is not solely that of world hunger in the poorest countries, but that the matter of food supply concerns all communities, even those in the most developed nations.

Trace some lines, as it were, outlining the essential coherence between European policies and this objective of global food security, because we are an institution that preaches very well but is often inconsistent in its choices.
I simply want to outline a few other titles—three innovative lines—that I believe we should develop further.

Initially, food supply today is jeopardized by price volatility due to speculation on food commodities—a phenomenon that must be contained, if not prevented, including derivatives and related instruments.
Secondly, the issue of land grabbing, which I believe should be the subject of some form of treaty, of negotiation, because democracy, as well as the survival of many peoples, is at risk.
Third, the consistency between procurement and energy policies.
We cannot, in order to produce new energy, prevent food from being produced for the world’s peoples.
I voted in a convinced manner in favor of this report by Honorable Zimmer, first and foremost for a reason of
a purely political matter, because I believe it is necessary to bring this major issue of food security back to the center of the entire European Union’s initiative.

It is not solely and exclusively about helping developing countries to address this issue more effectively, but the food crisis, since it is projected that demand will increase by over seventy percent from now until 2050.

Agricultural products are a significant issue that, if not addressed promptly and decisively, will become one of the primary threats, if not the most important threat, to stability, peace, and even democracy, as has been observed.

For this reason, I believe it is indispensable that the entire European Union, together with its Member States, make every necessary effort, starting with adequate economic investments, as indicated in the report, in this direction to seriously address this significant issue.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, greetings to the Commission. I must genuinely thank all the individuals who contributed over these weeks and months to the production of this document that we are voting on today in the chamber.
We have worked, I must say, very well, and a truly constructive debate has developed.
The resolution we are voting on today is the culmination of truly collaborative work and the result of the contribution of all political forces and the entire Parliament.
I believe a strong collective sensitivity has developed regarding this topic, partly because, we must remember, we live in an era truly characterized by an exponential increase in catastrophes.
The numbers, if we consider them in their raw state, are very eloquent. The number of disasters worldwide has quintupled, if we consider that in 1975
Seventy-eight catastrophic events had been recorded, whereas we are now experiencing nearly four hundred calamitous events per year.

In recent decades, unfortunately, the victims of these disasters have numbered ninety thousand or more, and over twenty-nine million individuals have been affected by them, while the economic losses amount to two hundred and eleven billion euros.
It is evident that we are facing phenomena of such magnitude that they demand a stronger response, a more effective response, and a truly robust commitment from our side.
We all have in our minds the images of the earthquake in Haiti, the flooding in Pakistan, and what happened in Japan.
Europe itself experiences flash floods, fires, and wildfires on its territory every year; let us recall the ash cloud following the eruption of the Icelandic volcano.
There is no need to look further to assert how important the work being done here in Parliament is, following two principles.
fundamental, which are our guiding stars—the principle of solidarity, strengthened by the solidarity clause of the Treaty of Lisbon—and the principle of subsidiarity.
We proceed along these lines.

The European Union's intervention has always been generous and effective in the past, as I believe the tireless work of our Commissioner Gheorgheva demonstrates, but today we need to make a qualitative leap.
A leap in quality that we are ready to make, to move from an ad hoc response to one where the reaction
be enhanced through the proactive identification of existing resources within Member States made available to the European Civil Protection Mechanism.
It is important to emphasize also that for this qualitative leap and to move from information sharing and emergency response, the role of planning and monitoring.

the coordination that we hope for, the fundamental role of services like GMS, and I take this opportunity to also express the concern regarding what is happening with the budget for these new technologies, which are essential.
We have emphasized the importance of communication with citizens because the Japanese experience has also taught us a great deal—it is never sufficient, nor ever adequate.
