and we await from the Commission, to which we request that it present the proposal relating to civil protection in legislative form as soon as possible.

oppressed ethnic minorities, Christians forced to practice their faith in secret, priests barbarically murdered without the authorities lifting a finger, anti-Western foreign policy – this is Turkey today.
My party, the Lega Nord, has always opposed Turkey's accession to Europe, because it represents a potential Trojan horse for radical Islamism in our continent.
Today, more than ever, we are convinced that the EU must bring an end to the accession negotiations.
The intolerable threats that Turkey has directed toward Europe must have an immediate response.
It is unacceptable for a third country to tell Europe what it must do.
Cyprus is a recently acceded Member State of the EU and has the undeniable right to assume the rotating Presidency.
Europe must send a clear signal and demonstrate its readiness to defend Cyprus by all means against the arrogance and political and military aggression of Turkey.
Let us immediately halt negotiations for accession and remain prepared to suspend commercial relations as well.
President, we are living through a decisive moment for the future of the euro and, with it, of the entire European construction.
Having this awareness would mean escaping a short-sighted logic that subordinates everything to an ideological insistence on budgetary rigor.
We all want the accounts of the various states to be in order, and we all want to reduce indebtedness.
However, it is clear that without a judicious investment policy capable of revitalizing the economy, there will be no possibility of growth.
The only clear outcome in this scenario is that the heaviest prices, as always, will be paid by the most vulnerable segments of society.
Therefore, together with the group of socialists and democrats, we voted against this report.
Indeed, progress continues in a single direction, that of rigor without growth—a direction that has proven to be incorrect thus far.
I greatly appreciated the work done by colleague Ferrera on this report.
Indeed, of the package of six legislative proposals dedicated to economic governance, only on this one did I and my group express a positive vote.

We did so because a clause for the protection of social rights was included, inter alia, stemming from collective bargaining, and furthermore, there is a strengthening of Parliament’s role in the adoption of delegated acts.

Therefore, while not being able to alter the overall balance of the package of six proposals, this report undoubtedly represents a step forward towards, among other things, a surveillance system that takes fundamental rights into account.

And therefore, in this context, while maintaining that, in our opinion, a vision based solely on austerity policies does not produce positive results, this report certainly constitutes a positive note of countertrend.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Finland and the Netherlands raised the matter in the Council for a very simple reason: Bulgaria and Romania are currently unable to guarantee effective border control and are implicated in rampant corruption involving the political class and organized crime.
It is not the populist parties and movements that think this way, but Europol in its 2010 report on organized crime.
There is no populist propaganda, but a serious security concern.

Should Bulgaria enter the Schengen Area at this time, law enforcement and security agencies anticipate that Bulgarian borders, particularly maritime borders, would become an easy target for Turkish and Eastern European crime, and Bulgaria and Romania would become a hub for human trafficking and drug trafficking.

It is natural that some Member States have many reservations regarding Bulgaria and Romania’s actual capacity to guarantee effective controls at the borders against organized crime and corruption, and it is therefore absolutely natural that they have opposed their entry into Schengen.
Allowing it now means paving the way for transnational crime and creating a breach in European borders, precisely where there is intense migratory pressure from Turkey.
The most opposing reasons are numerous, and Europe cannot ignore them.
I therefore request information regarding the intentions of the Commission and the Council with respect to this delicate matter, which, in my opinion, has been treated thus far with...
sufficiency, without considering the dangers that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania would entail, according to the competent bodies in matters of security and international crime.

In my view, the Commission and the Council should postpone the accession of these two countries to Schengen and give their approval only when there is reasonable certainty that the accession of Bulgaria and Romania will not have repercussions for the security of European citizens.
Mr. President, the crisis in Europe is interweaving the problems of public finances and private capital with those of the productivity of our businesses, and the spectre of recession looms.
Therefore, if the priority of SMEs is crucial, I ask the Commission to absolutely ensure, together with Parliament, that our good principles are put into practice.
and that the legislative initiatives of the SBA, the Small Business Act, become concrete practice for the Member States, with a high level of effectiveness and quality.

Mr. Commissioner, consider what it would be if all Member States were to expedite the implementation of the directive against late payments? What great benefit it would be for SMEs? Therefore, SME evidence is important, but we are still at a methodological level.

Certainly, it is right to verify whether when we legislate, we do so truly in the interest of and tailored to the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises; but we ask that proceedings continue with great consistency and tenacity in developing this framework of opportunities that you have outlined.
We appreciate what is being done by the Commission as well, and we are ready, with the budget and the other possibilities at our disposal, to support it.
I will say only one word about credit.
Let's have a clear discussion with the banks, I say this to you, Commissioner, because it is necessary to help small and medium-sized enterprises.
Mr. President, I have expressed my favorable vote for the text presented by the honorable Member Wallis.
Without prejudice to established avenues for accessing justice, I am convinced that alternative dispute resolution (ADR) represents a rapid and cost-effective alternative to legal proceedings.
Beyond being an effective tool for small and medium-sized enterprises, ADR can also experience significant online development for the resolution of minor disputes.

Through a joint activity with Member States, it is therefore necessary to promote the creation of a harmonized legal framework that, by strengthening citizens’ trust in the internal market, can contribute to stimulating the European economy.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the report concerning the provisions for sectors placed on the market under the flexible regime, to which we have expressed our favorable vote, was inspired by a measured and realistic approach that has

concretized, on the one hand, by avoiding the setting of unrealistic and impossible-to-meet requirements, and on the other hand, by establishing a so-called flexibility regime that articulates itself in the provision of temporal phases and corresponding quantitative limits of

Permitted emissions involve the market release of a predetermined annual quota of tractors meeting specific characteristics, thereby allowing for the gradual adaptation to established standards without disruption to the relevant production and industrial sectors.

The Honorable Tattarella, the work accomplished has been important and has demonstrated a careful balancing of the needs dictated by the significant challenges facing the European Union at this time, and those of environmental protection and the current economic crisis context.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the current global economic crisis, even more severe than that of 1929, has caused unsustainable imbalances in international economies in recent years.
Trade imbalances between countries, financial markets lacking common regulation, and the instability of banking systems are all potential threats to financial and economic stability.
This resolution, to which I express my support, urgently underscores the fundamental aspect of new rules and global economic coordination.

The economy needs a system of global governance, open markets, high economic and social standards, more responsible monetary policy, and stricter supervisory policies; decision-making bodies and international economic organizations must be the primary actors at the center of this new approach.

Europe, specifically, needs a transparent potential to reduce the exacerbated instabilities, even those driven by globalization, and to guarantee far-reaching reforms aimed at promoting growth and reducing the individual states’ debt.
This is the commitment that this resolution emphasizes to all countries.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I have cast my vote in favor of the report by my colleague, honorable Matera, which analyzes the situation of single mothers, who today represent, as has already been stated, more than five percent of the European Union’s population.

The European Union therefore has a moral obligation to protect them, and the text approved today supports those policies that can represent concrete assistance for these women, such as benefits for daily living.
healthcare assistance, flexible work opportunities that allow for work-life balance, priority access to affordable housing, and special unemployment benefits.
Only through the adoption of these measures can we respond to the needs of a category that is increasingly significant in all advanced and industrialized countries.
Thank you, President. The budget sets forth only a few clear and important objectives within the scope of the EU 2020 strategy. For this, a thank you to the rapporteurs.
It is essential to focus on investments and not merely on prudent balance sheet management.
The alternative would be to passively witness the speculative philosophy that characterizes our time.
We can no longer afford to pursue individual interests, but must finally represent a single, cohesive entity ready for engagement.

I commend the commitments undertaken regarding pilot projects and preparatory actions in section two, as well as ensuring that funding for the integrated maritime policy does not come at the expense of other initiatives and programs within the fisheries sector.

This will enable us to implement new policies towards a better management of marine resources through widespread research and exchange of data relating to fish stocks, imposing new designs that can be utilized in the Adriatic area as best practices in other marine areas.

I conclude with a brief postscript. Let us consider fish a common good.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, there are many workers in difficulty in our countries: the elderly, women, young people, people with disabilities, and millions of individuals and families brought to their knees by the crisis and speculation.
Faced with this situation, we are here to discuss plans for support of the Roma communities and housing for immigrants.

We must think about assisting those categories that genuinely find themselves in difficulty and providing both financial and political support to the family, which is the institution upon which our society is founded.
We must assist small and medium-sized enterprises stifled by the crisis, because these SMEs are the true antidote to poverty and the genuine source of wealth for our countries.
We must prioritize our strongest assets, not earmark them to guarantee migrants a minimum income that Europe seeks to impose from above.
Enough talking about Roma and immigrants. Now we must give precedence to the truly excluded.
If we look around carefully, we will see many, and it is certainly not necessary to enter a Romani camp to see them.
To these excluded, Europe must direct its efforts and its funds, now more than ever.

Mr. President, I have expressed my favorable vote for the text concerning the work of the ACP Joint Commission, which, thanks to the quality of the work it has done, has established itself as a key actor in cooperation between the North and the South of the world.
I myself, as a member of that assembly, participated in the meetings held in Brussels and in the work carried out in Tenerife in April of 2010 and in Kinshasa, Congo, in December of the same year.

It is precisely through these visits that I have been able to witness firsthand, as I did in Angola in 2009, the bleak conditions endured daily by certain peoples, and at the same time assess the efforts undertaken by the ACP to improve matters.
In conclusion, I feel compelled to emphasize, in a specific historical-political moment, particularly for the countries of North Africa and the Middle East, how the role played by the CP has been…

fundamental importance, especially within the scope of supervising negotiations for economic partnership agreements, promoting the transparency of such processes and the development of disadvantaged local realities.
Mr. President, honorable Zanicki, I personally find the establishment of a European heritage mark interesting.

At a time when, due to the persistent economic crisis, a degree of Euroscepticism is emerging in many Member States, I believe that an initiative of this kind could strengthen the sense of belonging of European citizens to the Union.

The defining element of the European brand is not the beauty of a site, but the symbolic value it has represented or represents for the integration of European citizens on the path towards improved intercultural dialogue.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, in December of 2009, I participated in the COP fifteen in Copenhagen as an official member of the European Parliament delegation.

Approximately two years have passed, and with regret I must say that the work accomplished and the commitments undertaken in Copenhagen, subsequently formalized in Cancun, will not be sufficient to achieve the objective of limiting the increase in the Earth’s average annual temperature to two degrees Celsius.

digital technologies in various service industry sectors, digital content production and new services, inclusion of currently excluded subjects – I am thinking of people with disabilities but not only that – defense of informational and cultural pluralism.

Mr. President, we all know how important the role played by the International Criminal Court is, which deals with prosecuting the perpetrators of war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide.
Unfortunately, in recent times the Court has been increasingly subjected to unjust political attacks.
His arrest warrants have frequently been disregarded, and consequently, the current balance does not reflect the effort and commitment expended.

I have therefore expressed my favorable vote for the text approved today because it is the duty of the European Union to undertake all political, diplomatic, and logistical actions to support the Court and guarantee its independence and proper, effective functioning.
Thank you, President. The phosphates present in laundry detergents for domestic use end up in European water systems, rivers, streams, and lakes.

Phosphorus determines an acceleration of the reproduction of various life forms; consequently, algae and other rapidly developing plant species proliferate extensively when there is an increase in phosphorus presence in an aquatic environment.
This excessive algal growth depletes oxygen for other living organisms, can also produce toxins destroying fish and plant species, thereby reducing the quality of the water itself.

I have therefore expressed my favorable vote for the text voted on today because it is desirable to reduce the quantity of phosphorus that flows into the waters of our continent in order to purify Europe's water resources.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the text presented by colleague Lisek analyzes the possible measures to be implemented to reduce defense costs during a financial crisis that heavily burdens the community budget.
The principal proposals concern improved coordination of defense system planning, the pooling and sharing of defense capabilities, and support for technological research and development.
I therefore concur with the rapporteur's positions, according to which the economic and financial crisis that has struck us may constitute an opportunity for the integration of the
European Union defence policies, setting the impetus for developing and finally implementing those ambitious reforms that have been stalled for years.
For these reasons, I have cast my favorable vote.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, a reassessment of European neighborhood policy has become necessary, following the Arab Spring and the subsequent events.

It is evident that, given the current state of affairs, relations with those countries must be more strongly focused on cooperation, so as to ensure the priority of democracy and security on both shores of the Mediterranean.

Regarding this, I believe that intercultural and interreligious dialogue is fundamental to strengthening mutual respect and tolerance with partner countries in the neighborhood, while simultaneously promoting the fight against terrorism and extremism.
For these reasons, Mr. President, I naturally voted in favor.
Thank you, Mr. President. Yesterday in Florence, an event of extreme gravity occurred, provoking horror and dismay.
A fifty-year-old man, armed, opened fire in two markets in the city of Florence on five citizens of Senegalese origin; two of them died, and three are now hospitalized in serious condition.
The murderer then committed suicide.
This concerns the racist and xenophobic far right that sought to kill people unknown to him, guilty only of having black skin.
Florence is my city, and before being elected to the European Parliament, I was the mayor of Florence for ten years.
Florence is a civil and democratic city, gold medal for resistance to Nazifascism.
Yet, this abominable racist crime occurred precisely in Florence, demonstrating that the Nazi-Fascist madness can manifest anywhere and should never be thought to have been definitively erased.

Mr. President, I ask you to express the European Parliament’s condolences and to reaffirm this Parliament’s commitment against all forms of intolerance and for the respect and rights of every human being.

in developed countries or countries not affected by conflict, with aid evidently hampered even by the stable security situation.

Mr. President, we do not have time to delve into the details nor to address the discussion at length, however, I believe that we must acknowledge that there are certain points that remain highly critical.
I share the concern regarding this green fund; in these times, finding the resources remains a significant question mark and a considerable worry.
However, I believe that to be concrete, we must acknowledge that this time in Durban things changed.
The old setting, which no longer reflected the actual global geopolitical situation, has finally been superseded.
Let us continue working on a photograph of the world of the nineties, a photograph that is quite old, if we view it from a perspective projected toward the year 2025, truly untenable.
We observe that in 2050, among the world’s thirty largest economies, there should be nineteen countries currently still on the list of developing nations.
I believe that this shift in approach is perhaps the most interesting data point from a political perspective and has indeed been highlighted by our colleague Florence with particular precision.
I also believe that we must no longer operate in silos.
Recalling also what Mario Draghi, the Governor of the European Central Bank, said just the other day in this very institution, if we also want to push this sector towards those priorities, namely…

Regarding growth and employment, we must truly be concrete and focus primarily on the technologies of the green economy to genuinely foster sustainable development and respond to the most pressing needs of our citizens.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Europe is shrinking, the stock markets are collapsing, the centralist Europe of financial lobbies is struggling, but the Danish Presidency opens its semester promising absolute loyalty to the Commission's plans for the creation of a super economic government of the continent.

Rather than focusing on the measures to be implemented to safeguard the fate of 500 million citizens, the Danish government promises to act as a faithful watchman of Euro-technocracy within the Council.
Other passages, however, I find entirely disagree with.
First and foremost, I fail to see how, today, accelerating the European Union’s enlargement process toward the Balkan countries can be proposed as a priority.
There are other issues to address immediately before worrying about how to integrate countries in Europe affected by corruption and crime.
And then Turkey, the Danish government strongly advocates for Turkey’s accession.
Turkey, fortunately, is well distant from meeting the parameters set by the EU for entry.

But the real paradox is that, at a moment when the euro is at risk, facing failure, it should be the Danish Presidency that saves it—Denmark, a country outside the euro zone—because, evidently, it has never trusted the euro.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the increase in infringements regarding intellectual property has been recorded in recent years…
years risk compromising the strategy on intellectual property rights in the single market launched by the Commission in May 2011.
To counteract this phenomenon and safeguard the success of the intellectual property protection policy, it has been proposed to entrust certain
tasks relating to the management of the European Observatory on Counterfeiting and Piracy established in 2009 at the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market.

This is to provide the observatory itself with human and financial resources capable of undertaking actions to counter intellectual property violations and awareness campaigns aimed at increasing consumer understanding of the risks associated with purchasing counterfeit products.

The favorable vote expressed in the report thus represents a moment of great importance in the fight against the trade of counterfeit goods and in defense of innovation, growth, and the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as of employment and the security of European citizens.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, intellectual property may appear self-contradictory in its definition, but conversely, it possesses significant moments of coherence.

I voted in favor of this proposal because its purpose—namely, to assign to the European Union Intellectual Property Office certain tasks relating to the management of the European Observatory on Counterfeiting and Piracy—is necessary and indispensable for combating violations of intellectual property rights.

The primary objectives are to increase awareness among public and private sectors regarding the impact of counterfeit precious metals and to inform consumers about the dangers associated with purchasing counterfeit products.
Based on the 33 compromise amendments, agreement at first reading was reached on 19 December last.
The modifications stipulate that the title of the regulation and the name of the office shall not be altered in the context of the European Observatory.
Furthermore, the important and fundamental thing is the participation of civil society in the meetings.
All of this will make a moment of synthesis, such as the one we are gathering to celebrate with today’s vote, even more democratic and participatory.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the report by the Honorable Lechner fits within that framework of actions aimed at improving services for citizens and businesses within the European Union.

The interconnection of central and commercial registers is, in fact, an excellent tool for making communications and the retrieval of information more accessible and, above all, more rapid for citizens and businesses.
Therefore, Mr. President, I have expressed my favorable vote.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, whenever the situation appears to improve, new credit rating downgrades arrive to shake the course of international markets.
Numerous European companies are facing a crisis, and on the employment front, the number of people, especially young people, chronically seeking employment is increasing.
If austerity plans and the defense of the euro are necessary measures, even more so are the profound revisions of the labor market at the national level, aimed at revitalizing the European economy.
Only by reinvigorating competitiveness will we give new confidence to investors and promote the growth of new jobs within the European Union.
Thank you. Honorable Bizzotto. I do not deny that it is necessary to protect the rights of homosexuals. What I deny, and this is the case in Italy, is that homosexual families do not exist.

Homosexuals will never exist, simply because the family to be protected, the one that the European Parliament should also protect, is the traditional family, that formed by a woman, a man, and their children.
All of this seems to me a rather elementary matter.
This is the reality that exists in Italy and in the other twenty-three countries.

through a work of satisfying the interests of citizens in their daily lives and especially of these millions and millions who, living on the borders of different States, exist.

and this makes a decision more flexible, given that there are such profound differences, truly very profound differences, between one state and another, which could consistently complicate the issue of succession.
