And it is true, this law is not perfect; there are issues concerning the testamentary executor or not, the practicability of direct inheritance, and so on. However, I do not only want to say one word of a political nature.
We hope that the Council approves this text, we hope that it becomes a regulation, but we must not put a final seal on this text, because we cannot even entertain the idea of.
England in a different condition with Great Britain, so, because Europe cannot do without Great Britain and therefore we should proceed to overcome these difficulties subsequently.
Thank you, sir.
Mr. President, the European Union has produced a vast quantity of laws and regulations to construct European law and has created the European area known as the Stockholm Programme.
There is a disequilibrium between this corpus, this legislative monument, and its utilization by citizens, which is numerically and proportionally very low.
On the other hand, national judges and national lawyers of individual States have grown within the law of their own country and possess a predominantly formative background in that regard.
sense, while we believe that the true European judge is the national judge who changes his mindset and becomes saturated with knowledge of European law.

Therefore, before discussing training, it is necessary to address a broad communication to citizens and legal professionals, so that they may become proponents of this significant development and foster the desire to utilize the advantages of this right.

But then, above all, it is a movement that must be generated from within the continuing professional development. One cannot teach as if to schoolchildren in the judicial training of adults who are professionally very accomplished.

It is necessary to stimulate curiosity when dealing with one's own cases, to connect with other colleagues, and to find solutions, given that today common law and civil law converge, are no longer as distant as they once were within the legal culture.

This is the crucial point. In our proposals, and I am pleased that the European Commission has been convinced by these aspects, we are requesting a reversal of trend, a bottom-up approach, prioritizing legal studies over judicial training.

There exists an example in the Netherlands called Eurinfra, which is very interesting; it is a network of responsible individuals in each court who disseminate this knowledge and encourage the magistrates in this regard.
The core of our project is this; we hope it will receive full support from the Commission.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would first like to express my sincere appreciation for the work done by my colleague Giegold on this initiative report, and I also recall that he and others share an active presence in this Parliament’s intergroup on social economy.

My political group, as you know, believes that the social model is one of the founding characteristics of the European integration project, therefore not a mere, one of many policies, but a policy that defines our project itself.

And in these times, with attacks also linked to the need for cuts in public spending, etcetera, we still convincingly defend this priority—knowing that it can be an updated, modified model—but we also believe it must be maintained, defended, and reaffirmed precisely as a priority.

Therefore, I believe that within this same perspective, we must also value economic entities that engage in business and produce goods and services, such as cooperatives, and that have a very particular role in what is known as the European social economy.

they reiterate that production is possible, good things can be achieved, and efficiency can be maintained even without profit as the sole objective, but rather with objectives such as employment, social welfare, the enhancement of labor, and contribution to the life of the local community.

Therefore, I conclude, President, that it is important for Europe to make available the tools useful for an active policy and to draft a sound statute, not the one currently in place, which is unusable, but a sound statute for cooperatives could be a way to assist this sector, which is so important.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the role of the Cooperative Movement has always been important in building a more balanced and more equitable economic dimension.
And at this moment, as we navigate one of the most serious economic and social crises since the postwar period, the role of cooperative societies becomes crucial.

There has been a robust development of the cooperative dimension within the economy, resulting in an increase in employment, more qualified work, and a more balanced redistribution of produced wealth.
It is therefore positive that the European Union has adopted a statute for cooperative societies, but now more than ever, it is necessary that there be a genuine simplification of the rules.
We need to reinvigorate the creation of a shared European framework in the field of cooperation, and this must occur by providing assistance, not by erecting bureaucratic obstacles.
Therefore, I voted in favor of this resolution and I hope that the Commission and the Council will actively work to resolve the issues mentioned.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the salvation of the millions of unemployed Europeans does not depend on the tenuous assistance offered by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Data collected reveal that the majority of the Fund’s beneficiaries are unable to find new employment, while the luckier ones are reintegrated into the labor market with fixed-term contracts, sometimes lasting only six months.
In many cases, it is the unemployed who relinquish this fund because they doubt its usefulness.
The fig is not a solution, nor does it plug the disastrous consequences of a European trade policy managed dangerously and with excessive levity by the Commission.

To combat the scourge of unemployment, now structural, Europe must curb its excessive openness to the markets of developing countries, whose unfair competition constitutes the primary cause of the failures of our businesses.
Until Europe ceases to promote economic self-harm, defending a short-sighted position regarding global trade flows, our businesses will continue to fail.
The fund can only provide temporary support, but it is not through training courses that our unemployed will find serenity and security.
I believe that it is a significant achievement for the European Parliament today.
President Buzek, when saying we must establish an anti-mafia commission, recalled that there were many colleagues from various countries who said, but the mafia is a problem of Sicily and Italy.

Today, to have received recognition from colleagues from northern Europe regarding the existence of organized crime within Europe, and to have the will to fight together—I believe this is a significant and important development, and I want to thank the President and the entire Parliament.
Thank you, Mr. Sondal, for such a comprehensive presentation.

I, too, wish first of all to reiterate our solidarity with the families of the victims of the serious clashes that occurred on December sixteenth in Zanusdaen, as well as our concern regarding the subsequent evolution of events.

What began as essentially a trade union warning has degenerated into the very serious incidents in which 17 people lost their lives and, in the days following the incidents, into the arrests of journalists and opposition representatives.

It is in the interest of everyone, and as Kazakhstan has also demonstrated firsthand, to shed full light on events; and I hope that today’s proceedings will be distinguished solely as a positive opportunity for our Parliament to delve into what has transpired to date.

and reiterate our appeal for an investigation that reassures the international community that responsibility for the events in Zanonzhen will be clarified and those responsible prosecuted in full respect for the principles of legality and the protection of human rights.

The delegation I have the honor of presiding over has had the opportunity, during some of its meetings, to hear the explanations provided by Kazakh authorities and also by several NGOs very active in observing events in this country.
The willingness of the authorities in Kazakhstan to provide explanations, as well as the promises of further clarification, are certainly positive elements that we must all, of course, appreciate.
I would also like to emphasize the need to maintain a certain balance, a balance which I had hoped would also be highlighted in the text of the resolution that we must vote on tomorrow.

It would perhaps have been more appropriate to defer action pending the conclusion of official investigations, to which an official mission by international organizations could have been usefully added.

The undeniable need to further clarify what occurred and the requirement to appeal for Kazakhstan to increasingly invest efforts in improving progress on the path toward democracy must also be consistently accompanied by a renewed commitment and an open and constructive dialogue with this country.

Mr. President, I voted in favor of this proposal because it aims to update the regulations of 2004 and 2009 in order to adapt the amendments to national legislation of the Member States concerning social security and to keep pace with the changes in social reality that impact the coordination of those security systems.

This proposal also incorporates proposals from the Administrative Committee for the Coordination of Security Systems, the purpose of which is to improve, modernize, and acquire, in accordance with Article Seventy-Two, letter F, of the previous regulation.

The changes contained in this proposal indeed aim to guarantee legal certainty for the parties involved and furthermore seek to ensure appropriate coordination at the European Union level of national social security systems.

It also reflects the regulatory changes that have occurred at the national level, and its approval was necessary because it takes into account recent developments in cross-border mobility that impact the coordination of social security systems.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the credibility of the European Union at the international level and the effectiveness of its human rights policies undoubtedly pass through the condemnation of violations, abuses, and breaches of human rights.

committed within the framework of or outside of armed conflicts, the mistreatment of women, minors, in general the most vulnerable, and persecutions based on religion or belief, but it is also of absolute importance to avoid disparity.

of criteria between the European Union's human rights policy and other external policies, thereby promoting democratization and supporting the fight against social inequalities, especially in times of economic crisis such as the present.
Mr. President, I thank Colleagues Asenis, Patraoneves, Romeva, and their assistants for having substantially contributed to the success of this initiative.
Fish is a common resource, as it provides fifteen percent of the protein for over three billion people, and the livelihoods of over five hundred million people depend on fishing and aquaculture.
This renders it a genuine global public good.
The approval of this statement indicates to the Commission a clear path regarding the need to promote responsible conduct, both among fishing communities and in consumer behaviors.

The debate on the reform of the common fisheries policy has, as of today, one more reason to advocate for actions that move European policy beyond the narrow focus on the methods of resource harvesting and an internal-facing policy of rules.

Conversely, a maritime strategy is suggested as a privileged location to increase its reproductive capacity, both in inland waters and through innovative modalities of fishing agreements with third countries.

After all, this is not merely the protection of the environment and the preservation of biodiversity, but also responsible fishing, economic and social sustainability, the specific interests of fishermen and our economies.
Thank you, President.
1.083.2006 presented by the European Commission in a short timeframe contains provisions aimed at creating a European instrument for risk sharing.

The objective is, in fact, to address the difficulties encountered by some Member States in securing the private funding necessary for the implementation of investment projects that can be financed only in part with the use of public funds.

Although the path to emerge from the economic crisis remains lengthy, I consider the work done to reach a compromise text fruitful, as it has set a ceiling for the funds allocated to the financial instrument and better defined the risk-sharing tools.
Please, honourable colleagues, the economic crisis, technological development, and demographic changes have transformed society and the labour market in Europe in recent years.
To meet future skill demands, many individuals will need to complete higher education, and many workers will need to continuously add to and update their skills and knowledge while already employed.

For this reason, I have expressed my favorable vote for the text proposed by my colleague Tocque, which aims to modernize higher education systems to achieve the objectives set by the Europe 2020 strategy and promote social, cultural, and economic development within the Union.
Yes, thank you, Mr. President. I will not elaborate extensively, as in the limited time available, I would simply like to mention a few things.

I believe that this seventh environmental action program may certainly prove to be a useful tool, but provided it is based on a vision of the future that takes into account the need to maintain a robust European industrial base, which is indispensable for upholding a dignified and acceptable level of employment.
There are some things that concern me.
A paramount priority is that this program ensures the most effective implementation of existing regulations before establishing

further binding objectives, and I am deeply convinced that to address today's environmental challenges we must rely on future environmental policies based on solid evidence and the most up-to-date scientific knowledge.

I am concerned that article twenty-three discusses ecological footprint as an absolute indicator; it represents an empirical model of reality, not reality itself, and we must keep this firmly in mind.

This has many limitations; it tells us how much we impact the environment, but it does not estimate, for example, the quality of the environment at all. Therefore, my concerns remain, and I urge everyone to take them into account.
When we speak of good examples for citizens, when we speak of the internal market and the possibilities of creating opportunities for growth,
genuine and concrete opportunities for change in everyday life through the internal market, can we truly utilize this example? We will need many others, evidently, as a result of our work.
It is a good example because, as mentioned, it impacts the concrete lives of citizens, daily life, and it also helps businesses expand their market, not because costs are high and services
reduced, but because they can increase the supply of services and, essentially, help the economy as a whole. Therefore, I believe it is certainly a positive example, a good example.

However, she will have understood, Commissioner, that there is a widespread will in this Parliament, particularly recalling the interventions of two of my colleagues, Marturel Goebbels, from my group, but also many others.
others who would like this example, currently considered good, to become excellent, and for us to move towards, in part as this measure anticipates, a result of zero roaming, because it is feasible.
We are utopian.

No, because a European internal market stipulates that rates should be equivalent between domestic and non-domestic users; there is no longer a difference when considering a single market, and especially because there is no technical justification for the increase in costs.
I remember when, in 2007, we began discussing voice roaming—the first roaming of the third generation to which we belong.
There was a certain incredulity and also a certain difficulty, not on the part of the Commission – I must give credit to its predecessor, Commissioner Reding.

Difficulties were widespread, arising from those who argued that the position of a genuine market does not envisage regulation of tariffs, that these are political prices, belonging to an outdated conception of the left, etcetera, etcetera. Conversely, there were those who claimed it would not work and so forth, that it would hinder the market, but in the end, we did it.
The citizens’ interest and the observation that there were no technical justifications for the increase in costs led to
Therefore, the world moves forward, things become increasingly possible, and for this reason, I believe a yet bolder outcome is possible.
Final observation, as no others are possible today: we received a delegation of Tunisian citizens, I don’t know if they are still present.
Perhaps among its many benefits, this extra-way expansion helps us understand that the possibility of utilization, without the specter of costs, also aids democracy.

In Europe, there are over one hundred and twenty million broadband users, at least seventy million citizens who utilize their mobile devices to connect to the internet, work, study, or simply access information.
Thanks to this regulation, the European Union has finally decided to intervene in favor of all these consumers, reducing the cost of international telephone traffic, voice calls, data, and SMS.
A positive decision, as the price reduction program will lead to an average tariff decrease of thirty-five percent over the next three years.

However, this is not enough in a challenging moment like the present one, both economically and in terms of employment. Communication, new technologies, and innovation are a primary asset that Europe must defend with greater courage.
Each European citizen must be able to circulate freely among the Member States, benefiting from the telephone rate established by their national operator.

Enough fraud and exorbitant bills for those who travel within the EU. If we genuinely want to provide a concrete response to citizens, let us therefore create a kind of telecommunications Schengen Area, which no longer imposes different rates on citizens depending on the countries in which they operate.
Mr. President, colleagues, I was a member of that delegation from the European Parliament that visited Sicily last November.
Our head of delegation, Cecilia Wistrom, has written a letter to the Italian minister; the interior minister chancellor has provided a response that has given us fairly clear answers.

I want to remember, above all, the fact that after that visit to Italy, the government changed, and the approach to the situation changed as well, but the situation itself also changed in the countries from which the migratory flow predominantly originated.
However, this should not deter us from the necessity of a careful analysis of what has happened and also of the current situation.
The most relevant fact that remains current today is the status of Lampedusa as an unsafe port, the closure of the first aid and reception center in Contrade Embriagola following the fire of

September of two thousand eleven, which damaged it but only in part—that is, one dormitory destroyed, one damaged out of seven buildings in the structure, and then the de facto termination of the project.

Now, aside from the consideration that in the Mediterranean the only unsafe port was Tripoli during the time of Gaddafi, and I don’t find this analogy flattering, considering that migratory flows, even if considerably reduced in number, even for seasonal reasons,

They certainly haven't stopped. It is important that a first aid and reception activity functions, and functions in Lampedusa, which is the first port of call for those arriving from the other shore after journeys that were neither easy nor without risk. The Somali shipwreck survivors who arrived know this well.

In April of this year, after witnessing ten people die on the overcrowded boat they were traveling on, or the individuals transferred from Linosa because there was no space in other reception centers, or the eighteen who still reside in the stadium locker rooms on Linosa.

And the tourist residence Cala Creta, where they are currently housed, is neither a CIE nor a CARA, and, above all, both the healthcare system and the possibility of requesting asylum have been dismantled in Lampedusa in the meantime.
Everything is entrusted to the good will and the generous hearts of the Carabinieri on duty or the citizens and volunteers of Lampedusa.
Another consideration to be made is the function the center itself had assumed in the recent past.

To have allowed, contrary to every legal and ethical norm, thousands and thousands of people to accumulate in a place that, by capacity and by the function for which it was intended, could accommodate only a few hundred is...

Allowing a territory of just a few square kilometers, already challenging due to its location and logistical difficulties, to be compelled to accommodate a number of people exceeding its own population must be referenced.
to reflect on the responsibilities for a situation of extreme tension that subsequently escalated into
the fire itself.
I believe that colleague Rinaldi’s excellent presentation was successful in the Chamber.
I fully share the favorable assessment of the report.
Nonetheless, I would like to raise a small point: our Europe, in relation to this new world seeking democracy and different economic conditions, is an Europe divided by the Mediterranean.

It is precisely a particular attention to the Mediterranean that I would like the Commission to devote, both with regard to environmental aspects and with regard to the economic transactions taking place in the Mediterranean.
The Mediterranean is the fishing ground.
We are building a new fisheries policy in Europe that will set very stringent rules on the part of Europe.
On the other hand, there are no rules whatsoever.
And so why not utilize fisheries agreements, supporting these countries so that those countries implement the same rules that apply in Europe?

This would be beneficial for European fisheries, beneficial for the sea, for environmental conservation, to ensure that this fragmentation is increasingly lessened, and instead becomes an ever more homogenous place upon which to build the future of Europe and this new world.

Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Parliament has become a fully-fledged institutional actor in the field of security policies and consequently has the right to actively and decisively participate in the priorities of the internal security strategy and the Union’s security model.

Colleague Borsellino's report identifies the five key sectors for which concrete actions have been proposed and advocates for greater judicial and police cooperation among Member States to address organized crime and terrorism.
I believe it is of particular importance to strongly consider the development of prevention policies, which are a fundamental tool for guaranteeing a European space of freedom, security, and justice.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the foundations have been laid for the development of criminal law integrated into Community law.

Notwithstanding the importance of mutual recognition and harmonization of rules protecting the presumption of innocence, it is essential to emphasize that law must be of utmost clarity and easily comprehensible, so as to make clear to all which action constitutes or does not constitute a crime.
This is particularly true for directives that must be reciprocal with national law.
Any lack of clarity may, indeed, give rise to divergent interpretations of the law.

I therefore believe that only close collaboration between European institutions on the principles and methods to be followed can guarantee a coherent and high-quality European strategy in the field of criminal law.
Mr. President, the European Union guarantees the general interests of consumers against unfair business practices, misleading advertising, and abusive contractual clauses.
There is no doubt that those consumers who are most vulnerable due to age, physical or mental health problems, or simply a lack of adequate information must be protected with greater care.
I have therefore expressed my favorable vote for the text proposed by the colleague Perez, because I agree that the creation of a strategy for consumer law
so-called most vulnerable contributes not only to their social inclusion but also to ensuring a single market that is safer, fairer, and more competitive.
Mr. President, the report by colleague Perez, to which we have expressed our favorable vote, concerns the need to consider the development of a

a strategy aimed at protecting the rights of the most vulnerable consumers, in anticipation of the strategy that the European Commission and Member States will be called upon to develop in this regard.
Consumer vulnerabilities arise from causes of varying nature and may potentially affect everyone.

For this reason, it is necessary to provide protection for this category alongside that of the general consumer and to develop, for this purpose, a targeted strategy that, considering the composite nature of the problem, avoids

On the one hand, the formulation of static and rigid definitions, incapable of considering all facets of the issue and the various possible forms of vulnerability, and on the other, a prevention of the creation of new types of discrimination.
It is therefore necessary to arrive at the definition of specific and targeted protective measures.
Thank you, President. The management of red tuna fishing has a long, rather complex history, dating back to the 1990s, and is currently arguably the most strictly regulated by the European Union.
Despite substantial investments in control measures having led to greater compliance with regulations, concerns regarding the issue of overfishing still persist.

I have therefore expressed my support for the Romeva i Rueda report, which proposes a reduction in the admissible catch rate, increased control, and a strengthening of measures for capacity reduction.
Mr. President, honourable colleagues, relations between the European Union and China clearly demonstrate imbalances at the commercial level.
It is therefore incumbent upon European institutions to strive to help European businesses emerge from the crisis and ensure fairer access to international markets.
I have therefore expressed my support for this report, sharing in particular among the issues highlighted by the rapporteur the application of the principle of reciprocity to the
relations between the European Union and China to enable fair competition in international markets and the demand for greater protection of intellectual property rights.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the road ahead remains long, but today’s moment may represent a significant step toward the introduction and application of a financial transaction tax.
I understand Commissioner Scemeta’s prudence, caution, and the need for gradual implementation, as well as the technical issues rightly discussed by Minister Vestager.

But precisely for this reason, I hope that Parliament expresses a clear political will, with a broad majority, to give impetus and drive to the initiatives necessary to address the problems that remain open, particularly at the Council level.
We all want to carefully evaluate the impact of this tax, but it is not fair to stir up unfounded fears, which can also lead to contradictory and counterproductive choices.
I am referring, for example, to the logic underpinning the proposed exemptions.
If one is attentive to reducing the impact of the tax, then it is important to have the broadest possible tax base, with a low rate, and not seek to indefinitely extend exemptions.
For those concerned about the effects on small investors, I would like to recall the progressive nature of the tax, whereby those who conduct more transactions and more
transactions, and it is clear that the relevant authorities will in any case need to monitor to ensure that customers and end-users are not burdened with any potential costs.
Therefore, I hope that Parliament will deliver a large majority vote in favor of this tax.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, since 1990, through the instrument of macro-financial assistance, the European Union has provided economic aid to countries experiencing short-term balance of payments difficulties in the form of grants, loans, or a combination of both.
The rather lengthy timelines, compounded by the difficulties evident in the decision-making criteria used to date, have necessitated the formulation of some regulatory modifications.

I therefore welcome the proposal introduced in the new regulations, which aims to make assessment criteria faster and more effective and to establish clearer rules and conditions for the provision of macro-financial assistance.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, there are approximately one hundred million European citizens engaged in various voluntary activities.

From major sporting events to cultural gatherings, the role played by volunteers is fundamental, nor should we overlook the work of those individuals who rush to provide assistance and solidarity in the event of severe natural or environmental disasters.
Volunteering constitutes one of the most extensive expressions of active citizenship and a crucial activity for the development of democratic values and equality within the European Union.
For this reason, I advocate for the development of high-quality volunteering, both national and cross-border, and the removal of existing obstacles.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, from the field of communications to finance, to transport, to energy, from culture to health, the role played by technology is increasingly relevant.
The increasingly frequent use of the Internet and digital media makes cybersecurity an essential priority on the European agenda.

Information and communication technologies can indeed foster economic and social development only if existing regulations guarantee user safety regarding data privacy and intellectual property rights.
Therefore, only full international cooperation involving Member States, institutions, and industry can give rise to a robust system capable of introducing effective measures to ensure cybersecurity.
Madam President, thanks to the Commissioner, you have said profoundly agreeable and important things.
I find it truly, as he said, striking that we have each lived in our own country with the numbers and figures we heard earlier from colleague Oconi.
But it is equally evident that this scandal has truly highlighted the need for a careful evaluation of existing European legislation concerning medical devices.

Unfortunately, this fraud has highlighted the shortcomings we have discussed thus far in class, which the commissioner has so effectively represented. Therefore, I would not wish to dwell on this aspect in the limited time he has available.
I believe it is beneficial to deploy all that is necessary so that we can offer the best possible to our citizens.
But I believe that this scandal, which has taught us so much, could also be a point from which to take a further step forward, and I refer back to what the colleague before me said.

The communication provided to patients is truly inadequate; only the positive aspects are ever emphasized. There is always talk of a kind of eternal youth, of promised beauty, but there are no prostheses that are absolutely risk-free.

I believe that this awareness, especially when discussing purely cosmetic surgery, must be communicated to people, to young women, because we know that there are very young individuals approaching this type of procedure.
I observe your consistent absence, and therefore I urge you, let us truly work; the deadlines are tight, we should have already completed this yesterday.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the Council’s regulations concerning the multi-year plan for ring-netting stocks were adopted prior to the treaty’s entry into force, thus necessitating an alignment.

This regulation, the first in the fisheries sector to be aligned with the treaty, is therefore of considerable importance, as the solution adopted in this case could impact the decision-making procedure applicable to other multiannual plans.
For this reason, I cast my vote in favor.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, from Seveso to Bhopal to Toulouse, numerous environmental disasters have struck Europe in recent years, endangering the health of European citizens.

The colleague Ader's text concerns the revision of the Services Directive, also known as Directive Two, which seeks to contain the effects of incidents involving substantial quantities of hazardous and highly polluting substances released into the environment.

The revised regulations, which will come into effect starting in June 2012, are intended to protect the environment and, above all, to limit tragic consequences for the health of citizens; therefore, I have expressed my favorable vote.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I too thank Stevenson for the excellent work and the framework he has given to this report, which substantially addresses the two main issues.

This is not a matter of a simple herring management plan; it is fundamentally about securing a future for fishermen in some respects and implementing marine planning to ensure that it, over a multi-year period, has its protections.
But the key point of this report remains the issue of delegated acts.

I believe that the Council must accept the framework established by the Treaty of Lisbon, and I also think that the time has come for the Parliament, in some way, with a voice perhaps more authoritative than that of the European Parliament,

whether in the debate within the Fisheries Committee or in a debate concerning a report on ringfishes, have the courage to take a very clear and strong position with regard to the matter of delegated acts.
We assert the right that there genuinely be the standard procedure on these matters.

So perfectly that the matter also encompasses, in addition to numerous other fishing sectors, which will, moreover, worsen relative to the ongoing reform, but pertains to issues concerning agriculture and other themes.
The essential element is the respect for the will of Parliament.
In the preparation of this report, no consideration was given whatsoever to those directly affected, the haulage companies.
In Italy, ninety-one percent of freight transport occurs by road.
Their rights will be disregarded if this report is approved in its current form.
In many committees of this Parliament, we are committed daily to reducing the financial and administrative burden on our businesses, but reports like this nullify those efforts.
all our efforts, as businesses themselves will be burdened with new bureaucratic burdens, ruinous economic losses, and new forms of unfair competition.

Little would have been needed to achieve a balanced account, one that would not overlook the right of our companies to survive during a very difficult economic period, but such a dialogue proved impossible.

Conversely, the report deliberately disregarded even previous legislative acts of the European Union, such as the 2002 Working Time Directive, and has even overlooked documents from the European Commission that recognized the hazardous nature of practices like retrofitting, which are nonetheless reintroduced in this report.
Colleagues, the document we will vote on tomorrow will ask you to disregard the positive achievements made in recent years, and European companies will once again bear the costs.

Just to say, Mr. President, that ACTA was a very serious political error—let us set aside the legal aspects—it determined a reaction in the world of immense proportions, and this alone is enough to say that it was a political error.
Why the blessings?
because it created the suspicion that access to the web was genuinely being closed off, which is a significant modern revolution.
And why this?
why did he make the mistake of lumping counterfeiting and piracy together, which are two distinctly different phenomena.
The way to combat counterfeiting has nothing to do with copyright.
And then another error that excluded Parliament from an important activity it has been undertaking for some time, which is the creation of a new copyright, a new author's right.

The old copyright law that existed before the web. The point is that we must work on copyright and set aside ACTA, which is an obstacle, and reject and exclude it, because it is an obstacle to our work.
Fortunately, the Commission, after months and years of hesitation, has brought two important measures—orphan works and the forthcoming one on copyright management societies—before Parliament.
This is the advantage. We work on this reflecting with our minds and not just with emotion, but without having pebbles in our shoes.
Mr. President, simply to add my voice to the praise this report has garnered in the Chamber regarding the need to strengthen the European Union’s capacity.
to be a place where it is possible to invest, produce, and manufacture in line with our conception of an inclusive economy, socially and environmentally sustainable.

Therefore, I believe that some of the guidelines here are very useful in this measure, others can be added, and I believe it is important to gather this guidance, to work ever more so that attractiveness prevails.
as a consequence of territorial policies, territorial marketing, and openness initiatives – whereby the territory itself proposes a productive and industrial vocation.

manufacturing and service industries that, originating from the territory, are respectful of all environmental compatibilities and, at the same time, align with European policies moving in this direction—a voice from the territory and from Europe that attracts investment and fosters growth.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, when discussing sensitive topics such as the authorization of products and substances for use in organic production, we are discussing the protection of the health of European citizens.

It is indeed important to respond to consumer expectations regarding the quality of organic products circulating in European markets and it is equally important to ensure adequate application of Community legislation by authorities, bodies, and operators concerned.
For this reason, I express my favorable vote for the colleague's text.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, following the initial comments on the Council, the phase of reductive reading has now begun, and this is incorrect because significant progress has been made.
Consider, for example, the severance of destructive links between banks and public debt, the plan—albeit weak—for employment and work.

It appears that the spirit of revitalization and a renewed path toward political unity is returning to European institutions after so much slowness and torpor, along with a willingness to achieve genuine progress toward greater integration.
Yesterday, we observed a strong degree of unity between Parliament and the Commission on this matter.

I do not speak of victors and vanquished, but it is undeniable that there has been a renewed institutional and political vitality in contrast to the past diarchy, which was the negation, the very antithesis of community spirit.
There has been an initiative and activism from multiple countries, not already to create new exclusionary axes, but to build a common consensus respectful of all member states.
This is the path to the political goal of unity, without which every banking, fiscal, and monetary union will be wholly inadequate.
On June 20th, with the Council's decision to return to Member States the possibility of reinstating border controls, a new Europe was born—an Europe courageous in fulfilling the desire for…
greater security of its citizens, inspired finally by a more mature interpretation of the concept of solidarity, brought back to the defense of the rights of its people above all.

To President Schulz, even though he is not present, I say that this historic decision does not represent an inter-institutional incident, but respect for the will of the citizens, and not for that Euro bureaucracy that for years has pretended not to understand what is truly happening outside the glass palace.
No fictitious influx of undocumented migrants, Mr. President Schulz, but an increase in irregular migrants, measured by Frontex, of thirty-five percent in 2011.

I regret only that the scenes of political sterility enacted in this Assembly, during the last plenary session, stole time from a more useful and constructive activity: questioning why, in defending the interests of our citizens, it was not us, but the Member States, who acted.

If Parliament fails to find its own identity and the courage to challenge the prevailing conformity and the sterile platitudes upon which it has maneuvered for too long, it will continue to be a follower rather than a leader in the construction of the European project.
Mr. President, I wish to draw this Chamber's attention to the fact that yesterday...
It has been officially announced that the Higgs boson has been measured and concretely identified.
The particle that gives mass to all the others and their existence—and this occurred on European soil.
Science gives life to our land and civilization and wellbeing, and for a moment we can aspire to return to being a world science capital.
Utopia is the characteristic of humankind that invents an utopia and desires to realize it, and it is for science and for this marvelous ambition of humankind that today a person
A blind person who lacks eyes can see with their hands or read a book with their ears, and a young South African man who lacks legs can run in the Olympic Games in a speed competition.
Indeed, Europe must be the home of science. This momentous event, which will open new frontiers to knowledge, must be fully supported by Europe.
Mr. President, honourable colleagues, too often within the European Union, victims of crime do not file reports due to fear or a lack of trust in the institutions.
The text voted on today aims to strengthen the rights of victims of crime and to guarantee them the same level of protection, assistance, and access to justice in all countries.
all Member States, paying particular attention to those victims who are at a high risk of suffering further prejudice or intimidation during the criminal proceedings.

It is therefore of particular importance to recognize victim status not only for individuals who have suffered prejudice as a result of a crime, but also for family members and the deceased resulting from the crime.
On September eleventh, the Catalan people demonstrated peacefully in Barcelona.
One million people have requested the independence of Catalonia from Spain.
On October fifteenth last year, the British Cameron awarded the agreement to allow for the referendum on Scotland's independence from London.
In Veneto, my region, over the past few weeks thousands of people have signed petitions to hold a referendum on the independence of Veneto from Italy.
Yesterday in Veneto, Lombardy, and throughout all the regions of northern Italy, hundreds of thousands of people signed petitions to obtain greater autonomy from Rome.
But even in Flanders, in the Basque Country, citizens are vocally demanding autonomy and independence for national states.
What does President Schulz say?
It calls for a courageous commitment to unequivocally reject all separatist tendencies.
His deputy, Vidal Cuadras, even worse, invoked the use of force against Catalan citizens.
Their statements constitute a grave act, contrary to the principles of that democracy which we preach and should defend here.
I tell them that the peoples will write the future of the new Europe, not the bureaucrats of Brussels.
The path is already laid out.
The austerity policy adopted to exit the economic crisis has not yielded the hoped-for results.
As highlighted in the report by colleague Lavia, only by investing more selectively and supporting the ideal of a European budget aimed at
Sustaining growth and employment will be possible by rebalancing the economy of the Member States, thereby improving the situation of European citizens.
For this reason, I have therefore cast my favorable vote.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the social and economic context in which the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 is being discussed is rather problematic.

With Member States committed to making fiscal adjustments to their respective national budgets to consolidate public finances, the European Union is, in some cases, perceived as an entity that exacerbates the financial burden on taxpayers.

Therefore, to truly emerge from the crisis and guarantee a better future for young Europeans, it will be of fundamental importance to support greater and more concrete investments in the sectors of education and development.
This constitutes the programmatic document of an institution. The budget reveals what it is, what it does, and above all, what it intends to do in the future.

We are facing a crucial choice between a budget of survival, of mere existence, perhaps a little less for everyone, or a budget of courage, of selective choices, of investments in employment, in innovation, in young people, that is, for the future of the European Union and its vocation for development.

All should understand that, as colleague Kalfin clearly stated among others, Europe can today do what states can no longer do for the economy, for regional development, for territories—where social cohesion is either established or destroys the lives of citizens, as we have discussed.
Major European decisions risk being stifled today by accounting disputes within the Council, but not only so, among beneficiary, paying, and payer countries.

We say that it is a false problem because it is easy to demonstrate, with figures, with numbers, not with words, based on what has happened in the past, that contributor countries, sometimes more than others, benefit from the convergence of economies and growth.
The Council is currently working to assign figures to the various categories.

The war of positions has begun: declarations, statements of position from certain states that consider the budget as just any expenditure that can be reduced without remorse, indeed possibly useful to bolster an anti-European sentiment easily stirred in times of economic crisis.
It is a misguided position that does not assist in the integration we are seeking to achieve in other fields.
Dear colleagues, our Europe is still incomplete and mutilated, as we have said so many times.
We adopted a stability pact that was also intended to promote development, but we have become so stabilized that we are in recession.
Here, let us at least seize the opportunity of this budget, this multi-year framework, to make choices in the right direction.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the lack of information and awareness regarding one’s rights, compounded by obstacles,

Linguistic difficulties and the non-recognition of diplomas and qualifications are the most common problems encountered by citizens of the Union when residing, studying, or working in another country of the European Union.
Unfortunately, there remains a lack of visibility regarding the concept of Union citizenship and its tangible benefits.
For this reason, I have expressed my support for 2013 as the European Year of Citizens.

The primary objective is indeed to strengthen awareness of the rights associated with Union citizenship and to assist citizens in fully exercising their right to free movement and residence within the territories of the Member States.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the proliferation of innovative financial instruments poses numerous challenges in terms of regulation, governance, and control of their effectiveness.
It is, therefore, necessary to find a proper balance between the objectives of transparency and control, as well as a sufficient level of effectiveness and speed of implementation.

The introduction of such instruments at the European level is nonetheless of great importance, as it represents a means by which the European Union, particularly during times of crisis, can stimulate investment in the economy.
in accordance with its own objectives, in a context where the continuous decrease in responses allocated to the Community budget contrasts with the constant growth of its political ambitions.
Regulation Brussels I has undoubtedly represented one of the most effective acts.
of Union legislation, as it has outlined the foundations of a European judicial space, promoting and fostering legal certainty among European citizens.
The revision of this regulation addresses fundamental themes for the development of European justice, including the extension of rules on
on the jurisdiction of disputes involving parties domiciled in third countries and agreements regarding the selection of the competent forum.

I am convinced that the approval of the new regulation can guarantee more robust consumer protection and greater legal certainty within the internal market, and for this reason I have expressed my favorable vote.

Commissioner, today you have requested from Europe a new task of coordinating industrial policies, and now even the most rigorous proponents of autonomy and private initiative are calling for the exercise of this role.
Without a greater Europeanization of national strategies, even in terms of employment protection, the current crisis cannot be overcome, and there will be no recovery.
The automotive crisis is not merely excess production capacity; it is a dramatic loss of employment.
But the crisis now appears to be structural and concerns the destiny of the automobile and of the product as it exists today.
We want to keep the automotive industry in Europe and we want to avoid dispersing existing expertise, know-how, and professional skills.
We therefore request that a large-scale project of renovation and revitalization be initiated, and that this be done swiftly, as costs are proportional to the timeframe.
Restructuring cannot be merely the result of fragmented national decisions or individual businesses.
It is necessary to at least attempt to coordinate and guide this painful process at the community level, bringing the interested parties to the table through social dialogue.
producers, trade unions, and governments of individual countries, providing support through research, innovation, human capital formation, reskilling, and the necessary funding.
I know that it will be an arduous task because the national interests of individual enterprises are not aligned.

But since the competitive dynamic currently underway in the European Union is very ambiguous and at times risks being unfair, I believe that ultimately it is in the interest of all countries to have an effective communal impetus and guidance to face together the increasingly aggressive global market.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the energy crisis has exacted and continues to exact a very high price from all employment, from thousands of precarious workers, but also stable and temporary employees, who are numerous in this sector.
The leading steel groups are increasingly orienting themselves towards the Far East or the American continent, and this raises a significant question regarding the direction of our development model.
I believe that Europe needs to reclaim the idea that a manufacturing system like ours requires robust basic production capable of supplying the European internal market.
We must therefore defend this sector and the role of a stable steel industry; we will support it, Commissioner, if we want to halt industrial decline.

I believe that we must also move beyond a certain dualism, which tonight has not been fully articulated but is often present in discussions on this sector—a dualism between environmental advocates and workers—which is mistaken because it prevents us from seeing a perspective for the future.
An industry that views steelmaking as an integral component requires advanced production systems, concrete and balanced solutions that safeguard diverse interests and needs.

Therefore, a robust planning initiative is required, even at the European level, focused on sustainability—an area in which, in my view, we must not regress—as a genuine value added with which we intend to compete globally, supporting investments as has been stated.

It has been stated by numerous sources: new technologies, new processes, the requalification of plants for a European economy that makes effective use of resources, including energy resources, indeed starting with energy resources, and also concerning the research of new and different materials.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, as we have recalled in this Chamber, next December the United Nations agency dedicated to telecommunication and information technologies will convene in Dubai for the World Telecommunication Conference.
The subject is the renegotiation of international telecommunications regulations.

We must not forget, and I am pleased with the words of Commissioner Tajani, the work that has been done to date and which cannot be called into question, nor can we allow the authority of the European Union to be circumvented by.

a supranational structure like the ITU, of which we know hundreds of States from all over the world are members, many of whom are known to have issues related to democratic principles, transparency, and freedom of expression.
Therefore, it is not incorrect to consider the pillars of the internet—freedom, participation, openness, innovation—to be endangered.

Therefore, I believe it is necessary to safeguard the role of the Internet and the role that, above all, the Internet can have in revitalizing economic growth, but not only that, also to ensure opportunities for all.
I therefore hope that the Commission will work towards the objective that Europe in Dubai is united and speaks with one voice.

Many controversial proposals have been presented at the negotiation table of the World Conference on International Telecommunications, particularly those that envision changes to Internet governance, which challenge network neutrality, with negative repercussions for consumers.
Therefore, the freedom of the Internet is at risk, or, more precisely, the freedom of expression and the protection of data.
What some states have proposed would, in fact, allow a government to meddle not only in the communications of their own citizens but even in the data transiting their networks.
The step from here to the restriction of freedom of expression to censorship is extremely short, and therefore I believe it contradicts the fundamental principles of the European Union.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I have expressed my support for the text proposed by the colleague; in particular, I concur with the rapporteur in emphasizing the fundamental role played by national judges in the application of law within the Union.

I therefore consider it necessary to fully support the efforts of the European Union aimed at improving and coordinating training in judicial matters for judicial and administrative authorities for legal professionals.
Furthermore, all sectoral initiatives should be intensified to fully realize the concept of the Union founded on the rule of law.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, in recent years the extraction of so-called unconventional hydrocarbons, including shale gas and shale oil, has determined a transformation unlike any other in global energy markets.
Europe, in order to address this situation and become less dependent on hydrocarbon imports, will therefore need to rely on its potential gas and shale reserves.
In this regard, some Member States have already authorized shale gas exploration and are preparing for the extraction phase should a discovery permit it.
In such a context, it becomes necessary to monitor regulations concerning shale gas extraction within the borders of the Union to ensure the effects of its extraction are more effective.
Extraction, without a doubt valid from an economic standpoint, do not create environmental problems due to the potential release of harmful substances into groundwater or the atmosphere.
Mr. President, I believe that today’s occasion should be used to speak objectively about Kazakhstan and the important agreement the country is negotiating with the European Union.
Kazakhstan is a crucial country concerning the stability and strategic future of Central Asia and is undeniably an important economic and commercial partner of the European Union.
This is a country that has already initiated a process of economic reform and a democratic process, but which still needs to make a significant commitment to bring these processes to full fruition.

It is, however, a country that, with this objective, continues to demonstrate its readiness for new and more robust reforms, and I believe that this is the task of the European Union to accompany them.

Therefore, I am certain that the signing of this strengthened agreement will allow for progress, because its approval will reinforce an already solid and productive relationship and ensure consistent assistance from the European Union.

I remain convinced, and this is something I believe should have been emphasized even further in the report we will vote on tomorrow, that progress toward democracy and human rights must be accompanied by a renewed, reciprocal commitment to open and constructive dialogue.

Our objective should not be to adopt a negative stance towards these and other countries in light of the failure to implement changes immediately; our objective should be to support the efforts of these countries to achieve that goal, including the respect for human rights principles.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, in thanking the speakers for the reports we will vote on tomorrow, just a brief passage on the spin-off, and I concur with what I heard this evening as a unanimous voice from all colleagues.
but I wanted to focus on artisanal fishing, on the Ferrera report which I greet and with whom I offer my congratulations.

I wished to state that with the past common policy on fishing, one has only contributed to increasing the disconnect between the institutions that regulate fishing and its true stakeholders, namely the fishermen.

Unfortunately, until now in Europe, the lack of a proper definition of artisanal fishing has disadvantaged those who have always understood fishing as an activity linked to the traditions of their place, their seas, and their cuisine.

Thus grew the conviction that the line followed by the European Commission was to standardize all fishing in Europe under large-scale industrial fishing, following only market logic and not listening to the reasons of thousands of fishermen who for a couple of…

For decades, policies have operated according to rules pertaining to ecosystem conservation, which I fully support, but which have never preserved the working activities of the microeconomy of artisanal fishing.
This initiative report sends a strong signal to the Commission and could translate into practical actions to benefit the small-scale fishing economy.
The report indeed highlights a series of advantages deriving from the allocation of a minimum sum to small-scale fisheries from the European Fund.

It will be necessary to incentivize projects with integrated solutions that benefit the coastal community as a whole, and furthermore, Commissioner, encouragement of young people’s access will be indispensable to

sector, we have discussed this several times in Committee because otherwise not only will fishing likely die out due to the depletion of the seas and fish, but it will likely die out because young people no longer approach this sector.
This report provides an opportunity to incorporate formative and incentive moments for young people interested in entering the sector.
Now, the floor to the honourable Toia, two minutes. As many colleagues have done today, I ask the Council that made this proposal: but what do you intend to do, gentlemen of Europe?
Do you want to minimize it, freeze it in the future?
But it is that very Europe that then seeks to be revitalized with the Van Rompuy document on integration.
But with what consistency, I wonder, is Van Rompuy conducting these two dossiers?

And what coherence can citizens find between the decisions of July, employment and growth, the lofty calls to hope and the future within the European Union that we also hear from the Council, and this violent collapse, and then, in the name of realism, in a perspective of minimal survival.
How will it be possible, with these figures and these cuts, to translate the much-touted major reforms of cohesion and the CAP into concrete actions and active policies?
These are sincere questions; we desire a clear, honest response, because here there are signs of institutional schizophrenia that Parliament no longer accepts, that citizens no longer accept.
Parliament desires consistency; it desires credibility.

The first criticism is that at the budgetary level, there is nothing but growth and investment—we are at the 2008 budget. It must be acknowledged, however, that regarding item one, van Rompuy’s proposal overturns the scandalous Cypriot hypothesis.
It is true, here the role of the budget is recognized as an irreplaceable catalyst for growth in certain sectors, in addition to national budgets.

But both growth and innovation, let it be clear, must not come at the expense of other sectors, which are also part of growth and jobs, such as cohesion policy, and also, dear colleagues, agricultural policy, which has increased employment and is increasingly oriented towards innovation and the protection of territory.

Growing Jobs is culture, training, transnational networks, the European Funding Framework, and also solidarity and international development, human rights worldwide, and our contribution to the Millennium Goals.

Before us, however, unfortunately, lies the usual spectacle of the Council: no vision, no guidance, a Babel of conflicting national interests, competing with one another, an inextricable knot of vetoes, expectations, and general discontent.
And Europe is, regrettably, the great absentee.
Mr. President, gillnetting is an environmentally unacceptable practice, as it threatens the sustainability of certain shark species that depend on those
At a social and economic level, as it involves the waste of a food product with commercial value, and from an ethical standpoint, as it demonstrates a complete lack of respect for animal life.

Although this practice has been prohibited since 2003 in European waters and for the European fleet, the Commission has decided to present a proposal aimed at eliminating even the exemption from the ban on removing shark fins onboard Union fishing vessels.

This proposal, in addition to further guaranteeing sharks the protection they require, will thus allow the European Union to actively contribute to the global effort underway to eradicate the cruel practice of shark finning in other parts of the world.
